speechtext: House again in committee on Bill (No. 120) to amend the Dominion Lands Act.- The Minister of the Interior.

This Bill was adopted yesterday with the exception of section 2. Upon examining that section I have decided to ask the committee to make it read as follows :
Section 1 of this Act shall not apply to any contract, agreement, undertaking for sale, or grant, containing an express declaration that it is exempt from this section.
This will have the effect of enabling the government, if it is thought desirable in any special case, to withdraw any particular sale from the effect of this section.
speakername: The MINISTER OF THE INTERIOR (Hon. Clifford Sifton).

speechtext:
Amendment agreed to.
Bill as amended reported, read the third time, and passed.

Bill (No. 119) further to amend the Yukon Territory Act (the Minister of the Interior), read the second time, and House went into committee thereon.
On section 1,
What are these sections of the old Act which we have repealed ?
This is just a re-enactment of the old section, with the exception that we provide for five members instead of two.
Will the hon. minister tell us approximately what the population of that district is now ?

According to the census, it is about 21,000.
On section 2,
What change in the law is effected by this ?

One change is this, that in case of an ordinance being passed by the local council which conflicts with an order affecting the same subject passed by the Governor in Council, the latter shall prevail. The second change

is to give the local council control of the traffic in intoxicating liquors, the section relating to the manufacture of liquors remaining as it is in the old Act.
On section 3,
Mr. BORDEN (Halifax), What change is effected by this ?

There has been a misunderstanding between my hon. friend the Minister of Justice and myself as to some changes which are to be made in this section. I have the amendments ready, but I wish to furnish my hon. friend the leader of the opposition with a copy of them before moving them. I will, therefore, move that the committee rise, report progress, and ask leave to sit again.

Before the committee rises, I would like to ask the hon. Minister of the Interior as to the legislative powers which the Governor in Council now has with regard to the Yukon Territory. My attention has been directed to the Order in Council which was made with regard to what is known as the Treadgold concession. the provisions of which seem to have a very wide scope indeed. If the Governor in Council possesses power to legislate for the territory in that way, I do not see exactly where they are to stop; and it struck me that it might be expedient for the government to consider whether some amendment should not be made whereby powers of so sweeping a character should be exercised not by the Governor in Council, but by parliament. It is not desirable that I should go into the details with regard to that particular matter at the present time. Possibly I may have some observations to make at a later date; but as my hon. friend the Minister of the Interior is considering the amendments to this Bill, I mention it now. The Order in Council may not be founded on the Yukon Territory Act; possibly it is founded on the Dominion Lands Act.
Partially both.
Perhaps it would not incommode my hon. friend if he can do so, to state now the statutory enactments upon which that particular concession is founded.

The provision in the Dominion Lands Act which authorizes the Governor in Council to regulate the carrying on of mining on Dominion lands, and section 2 of the Act entitled an Act to amend the Yukon, Territory Act which was passed in 1899, 62 and 63 Victoria.
That is the section which we are now amending ?

Yes. My hon. friend will see that that gives very wide powers. What I want to call my hon. friend's attention to, in regard
to his other observation, is this, that in passing this legislation the House practically followed the old North-west Territories Act and gave the same powers to the Governor in Council as were given to them with regard to the North-west Territories before they received a constitutional form of government. No doubt the power of the Governor in Council under the legislation as it now stands is very wide. The question as to whether that should be curtailed by giving exclusive power to the Commissioner in Council was considered, but it was thought that for a time at least it might be left in the shape in which it is in the clause we are now passing, that is to say, that in case of any conflict between the Governor in Council and the local council, the decision of the Governor in Council shall prevail. There has not been any conflict, so far as I am aware, and I do not think that there is any matter which has been dealt with by an ordinance of the Governor in Council except one. I think that under the late Minister of Justice an Order in Council was passed relating to the legal profession. The reason why I ask that this matter be laid over is because there is a portion of the old clause which, under the amendment, will be required to be left in. This amendment was not in contemplation at the time the Bill was drawn and that portion of the clause was left out. I will send my ,hon. friend a copy of the amendment before it is put in.

Orders in Council dealing with the disposal of very large interests in the Yukon apparently need not be laid before parliament or have the sanction of parliament in any way. That is correct, I think. What I would suggest is that the conferring of rights of so great a scope, and possibly of such large value, as those contained in this Treadgold concession, might be limited in some way. I appreciate the fact that it is necessary to give the Governor in Council certain powers with regard to unorganized territories, but I have not been able to persuade myself that it is necessary to give such wide powers as are required for the disposal of concessions of that kind. That is a matter^ to which I would like my hon. friend to give his attention, and when the Bill comes up again we may discuss it with the view to an amendment of that character.

I think the subject is a very fair one for discussion, and I do not think that the government desires any greater powers than are necessary for the administration of the territories. Of course, powers are necessary for the administration of a territory such as the Yukon, which would not be required in any other part of Canada. If my non. friend desires to make any suggestion of a definite character regarding the limitations which should be put on the power of the

government, I would be quite willing to give them the fullest consideration.
Bill reported, read the third time, and passed.
SUPPLY-THE CORONATION CONTIN-[DOT] GENT.
The MINISTER OF FINANCE (Hon. W. S. Fielding) moved that the House go again into Committee of Supply.

I desire, Mr. Speaker, to call the attention of the House, and especially the attention of the Minister of Militia and Defence, to a certain matter, resulting from certain questions put by me to the House a few days ago, and which has come to me with some degree of surprise, and I may say has caused an important branch of the military service of this country a considerable amount of disapproval and disappointment. On the 9th of April, a resolution was moved by the hon. member for East Sinmoe (Mr. Bennett) to the effect that in the opinion of this House, the military force to be sent from Canada to the approaching Coronation ceremonies should be composed in its entirety of officers and men who have seen active service on the Canadian contingents in South Africa. In speaking to that resolution, the hon. the Minister of Militia is reported as having used the following language :
All I can say now to my hon. friend and to the House is that I propose to recommend to the government that we should send a contingent composed of 580 men, representative of all the different branches of the Canadian militia ; that the different corps in the various districts of Canada should be fairly represented numerically , that the selection should be made with reference to the numbers enrolled in the militia in each district ; and that we will endeavour to have it truly representative of the force of this Dominion which will show to the people of England and to the people of the empire as clearly as possible the kind of militia force we have in this country.
If reference be made to the regulations and orders of the militia of Canada, tlie table of precedence will be found in section 7 of subsection 17 :
The following is the order of precedence of the several corps of the militia of the Dominion of Canada. The corps of each arm taking precedence according to the date of formation. 1st, the gentlemen cadets cf the Royal Military College.
Now, we have the statement of the bon. minister that each and every branch of the militia of Canada should be represented upon the contingent sent home to attend the Coronation festivities. We have then the fact that the gentlemen cadets of the Royal Military College are a branch of the militia force of this Dominion, and rank first, according to the regulations and orders of the militia department. In addition we Hon. Mr. SIPTON.
know that during the visit lately made by His Royal Highness, the Duke of Cornwall and York, His Royal Highness took advantage of tlie opportunity to visit the Royal Military College, and expressed himself as being very highly pleased with his visit. In fact he used-even stronger language to show his appreciation of the work done by those cadets. I am Instructed further, that in June last the hon. minister himself paid a visit to the college at Kingston, and during the course of his inspection promised the cadets that he would use every possible endeavour to see that this branch of our Canadian military forces would be represented at the Coronation proceedings. He further expressed the hope that the conduct of the cadets would fully warrant him in making such a recommendation. I am not at all surprised that the minister should have made that pledge, but am disappointed that he should have, despite his promise, adopted the course which he has within the last few days. These young men who are attending the college are sons of some of the very best families in this Dominion. They are young men who have placed their services at the disposal of their country, and who are obliged, in the course of their studies, to undergo considerable hardship. They have to spend a number of years of the very best of their lives in qualifying themselves to render greater service to their country.
Not only is that the fact, but they are obliged to spend considerable sums of money in order to so qualify themselves. .These young men have not only done this, but those who have passed through the college have brought glory to the name of this country. It is only a few days ago that the First Minister spoke of the' brave acts of one of the cadets of the Royal Military College, and could hardly find language strong enough to express his admiration -an admiration which is felt by all the people of Canada-for the bravery displayed by Lieut. Bruce Carrutliers of the Royal Military College. While Bruce Carrutliers stands out as a shining example, he is no exception to the young men who pass through that college. So, if there is any part of the militia of this country that should be recognized by parliament and the people it is that made up of the gentlemen cadets of tlie Royal Military College. In view of the facts that are so well known,
I was surprised at the answer I received to a question I put in the House only nineteen days after the minister had made the statement which I have refered to. The question will be found reported in ' Hansard' of the 28th April. It is as follows :
Is it the intention of the government to send a detachment of cadets from the Royal Military College to attend the Coronation ?	'	"
The answer to that question is simply ' No ' And so we have this state of affairs : First, there is the statement made by the minister

pledging himself that each and every branch of the militia force of the Dominon should be represented on the contingent to be sent to the Coronation; secondly, we have the statement made by the minister to the cadets of the Royal Military College that he would use every possible endeavour to have this branch of the militia force represented on that occasion, and that he hoped they would so acquit themselves from that time until the time came to send them to the Coronation, that he would feel warranted in doing so. 1 have letters from a gentleman high in military circles who says that, when recently in England he learned that the present Prince of Wales had expressed the hope that there would be a detachment from the Royal Military College to attend the Coronation proceedings. In view of the promise made by the minister, these young men have been striving to the best of their ability, they have been putting forward extraordinary efforts to qualify themselves the better for a representation on the Coronation contingent. And now they are told by the minister on the floor of this House that he does not intend to send any squad or detachment from the college to accompany the Coronation contingent. It is needless to say that these young men are disappointed. I think the country also will be disappointed. I would like to know from the minister whether the government have changed their minds as to sending a squad or detachment from the Royal Military College to the Coronation. Or is it posible that these young men, even in the face of the promise given them, have not acquitted themselves in such a manner as to justify the minister in giving them representation upon this contingent? If that is so, I would like the hon. minister to point out on the floor of this House in what way they have been deficient or lacking in their efforts properly to represent their country.

The hon. gentleman (Mr. Porter) has not been a member of the House long enough, I suppose, to become aware of the custom of the House to give notice to the minister immediately concerned of intention to bring up a matter of this kind. If my hon. friend had done so. I would, perhaps, have been better prepared to meet his statements than I am. However. I may say that this complaint is quite wide of the mark when it is based upon the assumption that there was ever any intention expressed or understood, or any promise whatever given, that a representation as such should be sent from the Royal Military College. I do not understand what the hon. gentleman means by a reference to a promise made by me or by the government to send such a representation. I understood the hon. gentleman to say that the Duke of Cornwall and York, now the Prince of Wales, when visiting the
Royal Military College, had expressed some hope that the college would be represented at the Coronation of the King. That is the first intimation I have had of any such statement being made. But my hon. friend need not worry. There is no doubt whatever that there will be, among the officers, and probably among the men, who will go over to take part in the Coronation proceedings, gentlemen who have graduated at the Royal Military College. The hon. gentleman refers to the cadets of the college as being part of the active militia. Technically they are. but practically, until they have received their diplomas, they are not members of the active militia in the ordinary sense of the word. When the question was raised, I think by the fathers of some of the young men in the college, I discussed the matter with the General Officer Commanding, and he advised me very strongly against sending these young gentlemen over on this errand. I will not go into details with reference to the matter, but it will be readily understood that if they were to go, they must go as ordinary privates of the militia, and it seemed to me undesirable that this should be. They are very young men, and their studies are not yet completed. Besides, if we accepted cadets of the Royal Military College, there are cadets of other schools of Canada whom we would be obilged to accept. We thought it would be impossible to accept these cadets without accepting representatives from the cadets in different parts of Canada. It did not seem to the general, and I approved of his decision, that this was what was understood as a representation of the militia of Canada. I have only to say, in conclusion, that I think I have as high an opinion of the merits of the cadets of the Royal Military College and of the importance of that institution itself as the hon. gentleman can possibly have. I think the government have shown, by the consideration which we have given to the college since we came to power, that we have the interests of the college at heart. When it is known that when this government came in there was a list of less than 30 students at the Royal Military College, with an annual graduating class of seven or eight, and that now we have 80 or 90, or more, on the list of the college, with an annual graduating class of over 30, I think the House and the public will take very litle stock in any cheap attempt which the hon. gentleman may make here to endeavour to show that this government are not looking properly after the interests of the college. After careful consideration, wre thought it was in the best interest of these >oung gentlemen that they should not take part in this demonstration. In conclusion. I repeat what I have already said, that there is no doubt whatever that among the officers and men of the contingent there will be found graduates of the Royal Military Col-

lege who have distinguished themselves, not only at the college, but on the field of battle in South Africa, and in militia service generally throughout the Dominion.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE (Hon. F. W. Borden).

speechtext: There is one matter the Minister of Militia and Defence referred to which ought not to be allowed to pass without reference, and that is his statement that the number of graduates attending the Royal Military College when the present government came in has greatly increased. It might appear at first blush that there was something in the contention the hon. gentleman wishes to suggest by that comparison of figures. But I venture to say that any one who reflects upon the position of affairs today as compared with what obtained when the hon. gentlemen opposite came into power, will see at once that the comparison is not at all favourable to the minister ; and in fact we would expect a much larger increase under the conditions which exist in Canada to-day. When we bear in mind the dominant military spirit that has been aroused by the recent contest in which Britain has been engaged, a contest which has been echoed throughout every part of the British empire, the feeling of unity and the desire to maintain the integrity of the empire being now everywhere prevalent, it is not at all surprising to find that there are a larger number of young men now attending the Royal Military College than in 1896. The imperial feeling and the feeling that animates almost all classes of Canadians to-day is that Canada, as an important part of the British empire, has reached a period when, by reason of its resources, and by reason of its increasing wealth, it should be able and willing to defend itself and to aid materially in the defence of the British empire when occasion arises ; and this fact is quite sufficient of itself to account for the difference in numbers at present as contrasted with four or five years ago.	.
The increase in numbers had taken place prior to the commencement of the Boer war. The college was up to its maximum before there was any prospect of a war in South Africa.
speakername: The MINISTER OF MILITIA AND DEFENCE.

speechtext:
I accept the hon. gentleman's statement, although he does not give us any figures as regards the two periods. But the minister must not forget that when the war was declared between Britain and South Africa the defence of the British empire had already been engaging attention in this country. As far back as 1894 there was a military spirit aroused in Canada in reference to the defence of the empire, which was expressed in this House, and which received a ready response among all classes of our people. So that prior, at all events, Hon. Mr. BORDEN (King's).
to 1896 we see that a spirit had arisen in this country which would account for the difference in numbers, and that spirit has been developing ever since. Now, we have reached the time when Canadians recognize that, having been under the wing of the British empire for so long and receiving protection for which we gave nothing in return, it is their duty, and it will be their pleasure in future, though perhaps not engaging in the European wars of Britain, to adopt some means of affording a reasonable measure of assistance to Britain whenever occasion arises, both for the defence of the empire as a whole, and for the defence of Canada in particular.

maintopic: EXCLUSION OF CANADIAN BEEF FROM IMPERIAL CONTRACTS.
EXCLUSION OF CANADIAN BEEF FROM IMPERIAL CONTRACTS.
speechtext: Before you leave the chair, Mr. Speaker, I desire briefly to bring to the attention of the House and of the country a matter of great importance to the majority of the people of this country, and at the close of my remarks I shall move a resolution bearing upon that subject. I refer to the fact that by an order of the War Office passed apparently in 1901, Canadian cattle cannot participate in the contracts for the supply of beef to the imperial troops of the United Kingdom. As I say, that was done by an order of the War Office, because there has been no legislation passed as was the case in regard to the embargo, or the statute, that compels the slaughter of cattle immediately upon their arrival in Great Britain. First I will read to you a letter dated Liverpool, January 4th, 1902 :

maintopic: EXCLUSION OF CANADIAN BEEF FROM IMPERIAL CONTRACTS.

speechtext:
Assistant Director of Army Contracts.
Now, I liave here the form of tender previous to the date I have mentioned, that is the 1st of June last, calling for the supply of beef from the 1st of December, 1900, to the 31st May, 1901. Clause 1 reads as follows :
The meat shall be well fed, good, sound, sweet and wholesome. The beef shall he ox, not under two nor more than eight years old, or heifer or cow, not under two nor more than four years old ; the mutton, wether or ewe, Carcasses of sheep weighing less than' 50 pounds will not be received.
That is the form of tender previous to this restriction being embodied. Then, this is the form of tender calling for the supply of meat from the 1st of June, 1901, to the 30th November, 1901. These tenders had to be in on the 24th April, 1901. The form of tender having been redrawn, and in the amended form the first clause reads :
The meat shall be well fed, good, sound, sweet and wholesome. The beef shall be home bred ox, not under two nor more than eight years old, or home bred heifer and cow, not under two nor more than eight years old ; the mutton, wether or ewe. Carcasses of sheep weighing less than 50 pounds will not be rereceived.
We now pass to the form of tender from the 1st December, 1901, to the 31st May, 1902, which is as follows :
The meat shall be well fed, good, sound, sweet and wholesome. The beef shall be home bred ox, not under two, nor more than eight years old, or home bred heifer and cow, not under two nor more than four years old ; the mutton, wether or ewe. Carcasses of sheep weighing less than 50 pounds will not he received.
Subject to clause 19 as to issue of preserved meat, and to clause 9 as to hospital requirements, the demand will be for the supply of home bred beef five days each week, and mutton (which may be frozen) two days.
Then there is a clause added to this form of tender.
Clause 23. Each quarter or other portion of beef supplied under this contract must have a label attached to it guaranteeing that it is the produce of a home bred animal in accordance with clause 1 of the specification. The labels will be provided by the contractor and should be drawn up in accordance with the pro forms as follows :-
The beef to which this label Is attached is guaranteed to he the produce of a beast reared in the United Kingdom.
Signature of contractor	
Date	190....
Now, notwithstanding the fact that this very important industry, as I have said, has, by this Act of the Imperial War Office, been 121
debarred from participating in this trade, it seems strange that our government should not be aware of it. It seems that even as late as the 31st of January the government, presided over by our practical farmer here, was not aware of the great injustice that was being done our people in that respect.
I say it is strange that such should be the case, but it is a fact, nevertheless. The lion, member for Russell (Mr. Edwards) and the hon. member for West Elgin (Mr. Robinson), whose speeches I heard during the debate on the budget, told us that all we had to do was to go to the free trade market of England with our stock and there place it. I would like these hon. gentlemen, and I am glad they are both here, to think about this. Not alone was protection adopted at the time the embargo was placed against our cattle, as I shall take occasion later on to prove, but, in a matter which the Imperial War Office and the imperial government have control of, it is total exclusion. Coming back to the point at which I referred to the hon. Minister of Agriculture, mentioning the date of the 31st January, I would say that this matter was agitating the minds of the people of Manitoba, and that it was made the subject of a resolution which was brought up in the form of a petition to be presented to this House asking whether this could be so or how it possibly could be true after all that had taken place between the imperial government and our own government. I, for my part believe that if the attention of the War Office had been called to this matter a remedy would have been provided. On the 30th of January the following telegram was sent to the hon. Minister of Agriculture :
Winnipeg, Jan. 30.
Please wire why Canadian cattle not accepted by imperial authorities for army contracts, quoting authority under which exclusion is enforced.
(Sgd.) CLERK OF THE HOUSE. To that the hon. minister replied :
Ottawa, 31st January. To the Clerk of the House, Winnipeg.
Regarding your question, why Canadian cattle not accepted for army contracts, I am not aware of any such exclusion.
(Sgd.) SYDNEY FISHER.
It seems strange that such an important industry as this should have such an embargo placed upon it and the Minister of Agriculture should not be aware of it. I was told by Mr. Wylie, a large cattle raiser and trader of Maple Creek, that this embargo made a difference of at least $5 a head because he said the contractors to whom they were selling took advantage of it and said : We regret that we are not able to supply this Canadian beef to the contractors ; otherwise we would be able to give you a better price than we are giving. I do not wish

commons
to occupy very much time. I have briefly stated the facts and I regret that the hon. member for Montreal, St. Lawrence, (Mr. Bickerdike) is not here, because I expected his support in regard to the matter with which I am now dealing.
That hon. gentleman (Mr. Bickerdike) feels very keenly upon this subject, but owing to the serious accident which befell him, he has not been able to attend constantly in the House. However, the last time he was here I told him that I would take an opportunity of discussing the question on going into Supply, and that I would refer to what took place between us. I cannot understand how the government can justify their action in allowing this very important matter affecting Canadian interests to pass without notice. I understand that the Minister of Agriculture has been in England since this exclusion took place, and as Mr. Wylie told me many of the cattle commissioners were surprised that he did not go to interview them, and that he did not exercise his influence with the imperial authorities to have this exclusion removed. A deputation waited on the Minister of Agriculture in Aberdeen with reference to the embargo on Canadian cattle, and he told them that if this embargo were not incorporated in an Act of the imperial parliament it might be dealt with. Well, Sir, this exclusion of Canadian beef from Imperial contracts is not incorporated in an Act of Parliament, and why did our government not deal with it ? Indeed, one would think, in view of the action of the imperial authorities in this matter, that they place very little value on the preference which Canada has seen fit to give them. It will be noticed that the exclusion does not apply to mutton, and so Australia is not affected, and Canada is practically the only colony whose interests are militated against by this order of the imperial authorities. It is a very serious matter, and I think that the House will agree with me that the government is deserving of censure for not having acted more promptly and with more effect in regard to the protection of this important industry. I therefore beg to move, seconded by Mr. Halliday :
That ail the words after ' that ' in the main motion1 be struck out and the following substituted.	'	;	t
It appears from the form of tender and contract called for by the British government for the supply of beef to the British troops in Great Britain and Ireland ; contractors are not allowed to supply Canadian beef for that purpose. That although this exclusion has prevailed since the month of Jun'3, 1901 ; this House regrets that no steps have been taken by this present government to redress this grievance by making timely representations to the British government with a view of securing the protection of the interests of the farmers and cattle dealers of Canada.

The hon. gentle-Mr. BOYD.
man (Mr. Boyd.) has moved what is practically a motion of want of confidence in the government, on going into Supply. I regret that he has taken this step and I think perhaps that if he had considered the matter a little more carefully he would not have gone to the extreme of making this motion. He wishes to censure the government and myself particularly, because, as he says, we did not take time by the forelock, and when I was in England last spring especially, see that this action was not taken by the imperial government. The action of which he complained was taken, as I understand it, in the month of June last, actually, I believe, when I was in England. I must confess that I was not aware of it then, nor had I any means of being aware of it for some time afterwards. It would no doubt be better tbat we should have the contracts of the War Office and of the navy sent to us in the regular form. That has not been done ns a matter of practice in the past. This form of contract in question was issued without any notice to us, or as far as I know, to anybody else, and it did not come under my attention until tbe early part of this year. It was known to a certain gentleman who is interested in the cattle trade, and who,
I presume, obtained the information from his friends in England who are interested in the supplying of this beef to the British army. The moment that information came under our notice representations were made by Lord Strathcona to tlie War Office, pointing out that this was detrimental to the Canadian trade; that it was unfair, and that he hoped steps would he taken to remove that restriction in the form of the contract. It will be a perfectly fair and frank statement of the course of events when I say, that since Lord Strathcona made that representation to the War Office no reply lias been received by my department. If Lord Strathcona had received a reply I think it would have been forwarded immediately to me, but of course I cannot say that he lias not received a reply within the last week or ten days. At any rate, no reply to his communication has been received by my department or by tbe government here. I appreciate fully tbat this action on the part of the War Office may have some detrimental effect upon the Canadian cattle trade in England. I believe that it will cut out to a certain extent our cattle from the market of the dealers who are filling these contracts. But I find it rather a peculiar circumstance that since this form of contract has been adopted there have been contracts made by the War Office for the supply of meat to South Africa, in which they have allowed colonial cattle to be received. I may tell the hon. gentleman (Mr. Boyd) that in consequence of representations which my department has made to the WTar Office, forms of contract both for the army and navy have been sent to Canada quite recently, and

these forms of contract are for the supply of meat by Canadian contractors whose names have been put on the contract list in Great Britain. The War Office and the navy have lately sent these forms of contract to people in Canada to be filled up by Canadian contractors for the supply of Canadian meat.
speakername: The MINISTER OF AGRICULTURE (Hou. Sydney Fisher).

speechtext: Has the minister any of these forms !
I have not them under my hand at the present moment.
I suppose they will be laid on the Table ?

Yes. The forms of contract were not sent in very great numbers, but I think they have been forwarded to the people whose names had been submitted, and who asked to have an opportunity of tendering for such contracts.
Will the minis-ted lay on the Table of the House the communication of Lord Strathcona to the imperial authorities, to which he has referred.

Yes. I have that particular communication here. I have not got the communications which have passed between my own department and the War Office in regard to contracts being let to Canadian firms. But I can assure the House and the hon. gentleman that while I have not particularly noticed the form of the contract In Great Britain which was a form for British contractors, I have been and my department has been for some time back exerting all our influence and all our efforts to secure from the War Office, and also from the navy, contracts for contractors in Canada to supply what was wanted for these services; and the War Office and the navy have both exhibited a certain amount of readiness to yield to these representations and to allow Canadian contractors to take part in the supply of these requirements. This indicates that while under the particular forms of contracts which have been quoted this afternoon as being entered into by British dealers and British butchers, they have required home-bred cattle to be used, they have not hesitated at all to take the meat from Canadian-bred cattle when it has been supplied or contracted for by Canadian contractors. I believe most sincerely that, on the representations that have already been made and the representations that are being made to-day in London. this disability also will disappear. I trust that it will do so, not that I fear any very great hurt to our cattle trade in England, but because I feel, as I think every Canadian feels, that our cattle in England 1214
are just as worthy to supply the meat for fulfilling these contracts as any home-bred cattle are, and that wre should not suffer on the English market from any greater disabilities than we do now.
The hon. gentleman has referred to the question of the embargo. In regard to that, I have only to say that over and over again, not only to our own representations, but also to the representations qf certain classes and associations in England, the Minister of Agriculture in England has declared that he cannot and will not remove that embargo. It was only lately, as I dare say. the hon. gentleman and others have noticed, that the Butchers' Association of London have made representations, in consequence of the scarcity of meat in England, that the embargo on Canadian cattle should be removed; but they received just the same reply from the Minister of Agriculture in England that the associated interests in Edinburgh did last year. The injustice, as I think I may fairly describe it, which Canadian cattle are suffering from in the English market through the embargo is one on which I think everybody in this House and this country is thoroughly agreed; and nobody is more desirous than myself to try to persuade the English Department of Agriculture, or the English government, or the English parliament, to raise that embargo; but the way in which our representations have been received by the Minister of Agriculture in England, and the way in which he has replied, has led me to believe that at the present time there is really no hope of securing a change in that respect. While thus quoting the Minister of Agriculture in England, I must also confess that Mr. Chamberlain, the Colonial Secretary, dealt with me in the same way in regard to this matter when I was in England last year, and he gave me to understand that the dictum of the Minister of Agriculture must be considered as final. Under these circumstances, I do not consider that it would to-day be worth our while or in anyway necessary to discuss the question of the embargo.
I do not know that I can add much more; but I am afraid I must ask the House to vote down the motion which the hon. gentleman has placed in your hands, Mr. Speaker. I do not consider that any fair or just cause has been made out to show that my department or the government have in any way failed in their duty: but they have taken the necessary precautions to try to remove any difficulty that may have occurred, and are ready at all times to work to the best of their ability in the interest of our Canadian farmers.

Mr. Speaker, the hon. gentleman's speech is largely apologetic. He speaks just like a school boy who has done wrong and knows it. and expects to be whipped. The hon. minister has first called the attention

3S4S
of the House to the fact that this is a vote of want of confidence, and he complains of that. Well, in the first place, my hon. friend could not well bring it up in any other form at the present stage of the session. He has been endeavouring for a length of time to get it before the House, but unsuccessfully. In the second place, I do not know whether the hon. minister should complain, because my hon. friend proposes to express the regret of the House that he had not availed himself of an earlier opportunity to make some effort to prevent this embargo being placed on Canadian cattle. It is quite plain that the hon. minister either gave the matter no attention or that there was culpable negligence or carelessness in his department. If he had been giving any attention to it, it would scarcely have escaped his notice that for over a year this position of things had existed. He above all others was interested in ascertaining in every possible way where the Canadian farmer could get an advantage in the British market. During a large portion of last summer the Minister of Agriculture was in England along with the Dairy Commissioner. They went all over that country, made speeches,! had reporters along with them, and had their speeches liberally reported; and the minister conducted himself in a most generous way towards the British people. I noticed in a report of one of his speeches that he told the British people how generously Canada had acted towards them-how we had reduced the duties on their imports, gracefully and deliberately, without desiring or asking any return. He was extremely generous about what we had done for England, but at the same time he was extremely neglectful of the opportunity which was presented to him of getting anything for the Canadian farmer in return. It was a generosity on his, part which the Canadian farmer scarcely expected. But this matter was drawn to his attention on the 1st of December, 1901, and although it had been in existence for over a year it was unknown either to him or his department. He could not have been keeping himself very closely in touch with what was taking place on the market which above all others is of great value to the Canadian farmer.
The very fact that he did not know justifies us in expressing regret that he was not more alive to the needs of the situation and looking more closely after the interests of the Canadian farmers, which he, above all others, ought to have at heart. On the 31st December, 1901, or on the 30th January, 1902. the hon. gentleman wired the secretary of Agriculture in Manitoba that he knew nothing about the matter. It is somewhat strange that the people in Manitoba and British Columbia and the territories should know all about it and that the Minister of Agriculture at Ottawa, who is supposed to be always in touch with the British people, should know nothing.

Does this not show that he is not sufficiently alive to the situation ? Does it not show a carelessness in the management of his department not at all compatible with the responsibilities of his position ?
He says that some contracts have been sent lately to Canadians to supply beef to the imperial army. But he did not tell us when representations were made to the High Commissioner to have the embargo raised. Had the hon. minister been as anxious to benefit the Canadian farmer, as he ought to be, he would have done as Sir Charles Tupper did, when High Commissioner. He would have availed himself of the earliest opportunity, and both by wire and otherwise put in play every influence to get the advantage desired for the Canadian farmer. Sir Charles Tupper did not wait for letters to pass to and fro between the Department of Agriculture in this country and the Department of Agriculture in England, but he used the cable, and used it extensively. He did not allow an hour to be wasted before endeavouring to get the embargo raised, and succeeded in having it raised at a very early date. But all the present Minister of Agriculture has done lms been to make some representations to the High Commissioner in London, and we are not informed whether these were made one, two or three months ago, but he tells us he has no information about the matter to-day. Ho has been content to rest on his oars, apparently indifferent as to whether the High Commissioner sends him a reply in six months or not. I think, therefore, that this House should express regret that the hon. minister did not take action earlier or was not more alive to the situation in the interests of our Canadian farmers than he has shown himself to be.

If the hon. gentleman had drawn this motion on broader lines, and with the idea of getting rid of the grievance complained of, I would be most happy to support him. I consider this a pressing matter, and drew the attention of the House to it at the very beginning of the session, when I moved for the correspondence relating to the embargo on Canadian cattle. I regret that my hon. friend should have made his motion with the sole object of casting blame on the Minister of Agriculture, when the Minister of Agriculture is really not the guilty party. It is the British government and parliament who are to blame. And had the hon. gentleman simply asked this parliament to protest against the glaring Injustice inflicted by the British government and parliament on the Canadian people by this embargo on Canadian cattle, I would have been glad to vote for his motion. The hon. gentleman has told us that the British Minister of Agriculture, the Rt. Hon. Mr. Han-bury. declared last year that were it not for the statute, the general question of the embargo on Canadian cattle might be dealt

with. But my hon. friend has evidently forgotten what Mr. Hanbury did say. If he will refer to the Montreal ' Star,' of the 26th October last, and the Montreal ' Herald' of the 30th October last, he will find that what Mr. Hanbury did say was that so long as he would be Minister of Agriculture, not only would the statute remain as it was, but he would never ask the British parliament to remedy the injustice. Therefore if we are to blame anybody, we should blame the British government. I believe that this parliament should express its opinion, not in any spirit of anger, but in a dignified, temperate manner, on the injustice perpetrated, and ask the British goverment and parliament to remedy that injustice. In my opinion, we should urge upon the British government and parliament the propriety and the justice of abrogating or amending that statute. But so far as Canada is concerned, if anybody is open to blame, it is our High Commissioner in London. I do not say that he is, but I say that when we pay $10,000 a year to a High Commissioner to represent us in London, and when we maintain a staff of officials in London, to keep us in touch with the British government, and report upon any matter of importance, it is their duty to inform immediately the Canadian government of anything that may transpire. Surely the High Commissioner should be made aware of what is done against Canadian interests before any minister in Canada. I should suppose that the reason we employ the High Commissioner is that he may keep us informed of any advantage we may obtain in Great Britain, and of any disadvantage we may have to contend against. But I am afraid that he is so busy complying with the wishes of Mr. Chamberlain, that he has no time to look after the interests of Canadians. I am afraid that Lord Strathcona, with all due respect for his devotion to Canada, is so busy supplying live stock to the British army that he has no time to look after the interests of our cattle raisers who want to supply it with dead meat beef. I think it only right that 1 should correct tiie mistake of my hon. friend in quoting the words of Mr. Hanbury.

What I said was that in discussing this matter in Scotland, before a deputation of farmers, Mr. Hanbury said that there was a statute passed as late as 1896. and for that reason he covdd not consider their representations. The words my hon. friend has quoted, Mr. Hanbury used later on.

But if my hon. friend wants us to be really aware of the position in England, he should nut lay the whole blame on the Minister of Agriculture here, but let us understand that not only is the Minister of Agriculture in England prevented by statute from acting, but he has stated most positively that he would not act so long as he continued to be Minister of
Agriculture. As far as the Minister of Agriculture here is concerned, I am glad to say that I was present in England at the time he was making all the efforts he could in our behalf, and I know that he did not neglect anything possible to bring about a change in the feelings of the British people. In saying this, I am not moved by any purpose of flattering the Minister of Agriculture or the government in general. I think that the position I occupy in this House will free me from any imputation of that kind. When I give credit to the government, it is simply because I believe it is due, and when I blame the government it is equally because, in my opinion, they are deserving of blame.
You don't blame them very often.

There is one point on which I differ with the Minister of Agriculture and it is this. I do not agree that because Mr. Chamberlain and Mr. Hanbury have said that they will not correct the wrong, we should therefore submit. I believe that this parliament ought to give expression to its views and transmit those views to the British government and parliament. The hon. gentleman has just admitted that this is an injustice. He has said that at the present moment there is no reason for keeping this exclusion Act in force against Canadian cattle. Therefore, I say that no session of this parliament should pass without a direct expression of opinion being given by a unanimous voice of this House protesting against the injustice, so long as it is not corrected. Those who have the right to complain of this injustice are the representatives of the Canadian people, and they should protest. I regret that the hon. gentleman has not brought forward his motion in this broad spirit, and I hope that the session will not pass without a motion directed by this spirit being proposed, a motion designed to convey the protest of the representatives of the Canadian people but without the intention of making political capital for one side or the other.

The subject which has been brought to the attention of the House by the hon. member for Macdonald (Mr. Boyd) is one of very great importance, I think we will all agree, to the people of Canada as a whole, but more particularly to our ranchers and farmers. The South African war is the opening up of a new market, we might say, causing an increased demand for many of the products of our farmers, especially for our hay, our flour, and our meats. But we can only look upon it as a temporary market. And, as we raise so much more of articles of this character than we require for home consumption and must And an export market. it behooves us to have every possible restriction or embargo that might tend to

hamper this trade removed, whether it refers to the army in South Africa or in the British Isles. So far as the slaughtering of our cattle at the port of entry into Great Britain is concerned, that embargo has existed for a number of years past. The Minister of Agriculture (Hon. Mr. Fisher) has told us that he has given up all idea of having that embargo removed through representations (to the British authorities, that, in fact, he has practically ceased all efforts in that direction. But if the hon. minister has not been any more prompt in his efforts to have that embargo removed than he has been in the matter of having the clause in the contract prohibiting the use of outside beef in the army contracts, I do not wonder that he despairs of having the embargo removed in the near future. Whatever show of colour there may have been at the time the embargo was placed upon our cattle, on the ground of disease- and I believe that there may have been some cases of disease among American cattle- there has been no reason for it in the way of an ascertained case of pleuro pneumonia amongst our Canadian cattle since that embargo was adopted. So, we are driven to the conclusion that the embargo is intended simply as a measure of protection to the cattle raisers of Great Britain. And this clause of the contracts for army beef is simply designed for the same purpose. It seems a rather peculiar condition of affairs that, while Canada has granted a preference in trade matters to Great Britain, allowing the products of her manufacturers to come into this country at 33J per cent below our usual tariff, and, while our boys have been in South Africa fighting the battles of the empire, where they are privileged to eat Canadian beef, the remainder of the British soldiers in England are prevented from eating Canadian beef. Actually our beef is prohibited and not a pound can be supplied for the use of the imperial troops on account of this clause in the contract. It may be that the home government is taking the Minister of Agriculture at his word. As the hon. member for East Grey (Mr. Sproule) said when the hon. minister was in England, he advised the statesmen of Great Britain that we did not desire any return for the preference we granted to Great Britain in our markets. This measure not merely does not grant us a preference so far as our beef is concerned-I am not aware that any has been asked-but places a prohibition upon Canadian beef, shuts it out from competition with the old country beef. Some may think that this is no very great loss to the cattle raisers of Canada. But we have heard an hon. gentleman who is engaged in the trade declare here to-day that at least forty per cent of our North-west cattle were used in connection with the supplying of beef to the army, and also that this clause means that a loss of at least $5 a head on these 1 Mr. ROCHE (Marnuette).
cattle shipped from Canada has been incurred. The loss, therefore, is a very serious one. But, even if there were no financial loss at all, from a sentimental standpoint the condition is most undesirable. Our government has allowed sentiment to move us in changing our commercial arrangements with the mother land. The sentiment of imperialism now prevails, and the tendency in business, as in other matters, is to draw the empire together. To have this additional embargo placed upon Canadian beef at this time is most unwjse. It may be a business move on the part of Great Britain, but it seems rather strange for a free trade government to adopt a course not of protection but of what is worse, prohibition. It seems also that Canadians might well take a lesson from this example, that Canadian statesmen should learn to look after the interests of Canada. I am quite in accord with the Prime Minister in the declaration he made not very long ago that John Bull will respect us all the more, the more we take care of our own interests. Now, the hon. member for Labelle (Mr. Bourassa) says he cannot support this resolution because it condems this government. The hon. member is always ready to give advice to this government, he is always ready to be the adviser of the British government, to be even the censor of that government and to condemn it strongly ; but when it comes to condemning his own leader, of course he will not do that.
If the hon. gentleman will allow me I would like to say that I have voted more often against my party than he has voted against his.

That shows that the hon. gentleman's party is more frequently wrong than my party is. Besides, I do not pose as an independent member of the House or as the leader of a third or fourth party. The hon. member (Mr. Bourassa) says he cannot condemn this government, because they have exercised due diligence in the matter, and that it is the fault of the British government. But, considering that these tenders had to be put in in April of last year and that a whole year has gone by, it seems clear that the Minister of Agriculture has not exercised the diligence he should have shown. And, when the matter was brought to his attention last January by the clerk of the legislative assembly in Manitoba, the hon. minister admitted that he knew nothing about it whatever. One would imagine that in such a case as this a clause referring to a matter under his own department, a matter so important as the supply of the army rations, the hon. Minister of Agriculture would be the first man in Canada to be seized of the facts and the man who would take the first and promptest measure. But the records show that, as I say, he knew nothing about the matter until his attention was

called to it last January by the clerk of the legislative assembly of Manitoba. Therefore, we have a right to condemn the hon. gentleman for not being as diligent as he should have been, and for not taking steps for doing away with this clause in the contract. A series of resolutions were passed by the legislature of Manitoba last February, just prior to the prorogation of the legislature, urging upon the Dominion government the necessity of petitioning the imperial authorities in favour of allowing bur cattle to be placed on the same footing as the cattle of Great Britain in relation to these contracts. Those resolutions were passed unanimously. They were moved by a man who is a large exporter of cattle. Evidently, the people of the North-west look upon this as a most important matter and one that, unless a change is made, will have a serious detrimental effect upon the interests of our people. Therefore, I view this differently from the hon. member for Labelle, and think that the resolution introduced by the hon. member for Macdonald is worthy of the support of every Conservative member of the House and of every independent member as well.

I feel disposed to adopt a middle course in this matter, because it seems to me that both the British government and our own government are to blame. I do not believe that the home government will vary from the course that is indicated to us by Mr. Hanbury's speech. And why should they ? There is no doubt that if they admit our own beef on the same footing as the home-bred beef, they will do a certain amount of injury to the stock-raisers of the British Isles, their own constituents; and I doubt very much if any pressure we can bring to bear upon them would lead them to remove that impediment to our trade. Where I find the action of the home government at fault is in the fact that we ourselves having given them a considerable preference in our market, and having, as indicated by my hon. friends from the west, made considerable sacrifices, particularly of late years, in defence of the flag, it seems to me that under these circumstances we would be entitled to more consideration. But as to our being successful in any representations we may make, I doubt very much. The language of Mr. Hanbury, as quoted by the hon. member for Labelle (Mr. Bourassa), is much more positive than is generally used by British statesmen, and I think we may regard it as a certainty that our efforts for a long time to come in that direction will be fruitless.
But I wish particularly to point out that our own government has in that respect a duty to perform, and that the Minister of Agriculture has totally failed to perform that duty. I believe that when the House is in session it is the prerogative of the House to express its opinion on matters of this kind; and during the recess, it belongs to the department interested to make proper representations to the home government in trade matters of this magnitude which concern the welfare of our agriculture. It is the duty of the Minister of Agriculture at any time, and at very short notice, to make proper representations to foreign authorities, and to the home government particularly, when that is necessary for the preservation of our interests.	The question which arises in my
mind is, What has the Minister of Agriculture done under the present circumstances 1 He has had three or four days' notice at least of this motion, and what has he brought down to the House to show that he has used diligence ? A motion such as that made by my hon. friend (Mr. Boyd) places upon the Minister of Agriculture the obligation of showing that he has used diligence in the premises.
I never had any notice of a motion. The hon. gentleman said he was going to make some remarks about this matter, but until he moved this motion this afternoon we never knew anything about it.

Agriculture excited the interest of our commissioner in England ; it was correspondence, a copy of which is here found, from one of the cattle ranchers, if I am not mistaken; a private individual interested in the cattle trade took up this question and brought it to the notice of Lord Strath-cona. Lord Strathcona having communicated with the War Office, he was not sure, was not certain, but he imagined that possibly the Minister of Agriculture might take some interest in this matter, and sent him over this correspondence. Therefore, though I agree with the bon. member for Labelle in thinking that the British government is at fault, if we are to take the view expressed by the hon. member for Marquette (Mr. Roche), still it seems to me it is impossible not to arrive at the conclusion that the Minister of Agriculture has not moved one step in this matter, or at least, he has not seen fit to lay before the House proof of any diligence whatever. What we have from him is the proof that he knew nothing about the matter, and a letter from our commissioner in London inviting his attention to the matter, and to the correspondence which he, upon his own responsibility, had had with the War Office. With what result ? None whatever. That restriction pointed out by the hon. member for Macdonald (Mr. Boyd) still exists, and in my opinion will continue to exist. The Minister of Agriculture will not deny that it exists, and we are precluded from supplying beef to the British army. Out cattle'are excluded today as they were a month ago. There is no change, the Minister of Agriculture knows it. It may be true that for supplying the army in the field in South Africa, as competition has been invited from all quarters. as there are contracts with the Americans, so there may be contracts with the people of this country for furnishing these war supplies. But will the minister state here on his responsibility that the restriction complained of by the hon. member for Macdonald has been removed, and that that form of contract is to-day changed ? If he will make that statement" he will enlighten the House on the point that we are discussing.
Under these circumstances it seems to me that there is ground for the claim that these things have occurred, and that they have been brought to the notice of the minister, although that should have been unnecessary. That should have been unnecessary. That hon. gentleman was travelling in England last year and surely this was the matter which might have caught his attention without his attention having been specially called to it.
He was treading on air.

I do not say that, but I do say that he, having been in England, when Mr. MONK.
this important matter was brought to his attention he failed to ustrdiligence. Under these circumstances it is our duty to say that he has been lacking. Now, I am not going [DOT] to take up any further time upon this question, but it is a matter which invites the attention and consideration of all the members of this House. When year after year, we have given a preference to the home government, in our markets, a preference which I. for one, and I believe some hon. members on this side of the House, claim has been a disastrous one [DOT] to our own industries in many respects, we find here, as I have found on more than one occasion, that our own interests on the other side have not been guarded as they should have been. I will not carry this discussion any further.

Mr. Speaker, I rise for the purpose of asking any of those hon. gentlemen who have spoken on the other side of the House what reason was given by the British government for the exclusion of Canadian cattle. They have not been pleased to enlighten us on this subject.

I suppose the hon. gentleman (Mr. Roche, Halifax) does not ask me to enlighten him on that subject. I suppose, however, that there are two reasons, one perhaps resulting from this embargo on our cattle and another probably from the praiseworthy desire to encourage their own stock raisers. I do not blame them.
Did they keep out Canadian cattle because they were diseased or for any reason of that kind.
I think it was deceased cattle they wanted.

Mr. Speaker, I just wish to say that the correspondence which has been referred to by the hon. member for Jacques Cartier (Mr. Monk) has completely met the argument of the hon. member for Labelle (Mr. Bourassa) that it was the High Commissioner in London who was in a sense responsible for the injury done to Canada in the contracts, or the tenders for food supplies for the Britisli army. I cannot see how tile hon. member for Labelle can possibly drag the name of the High Commissioner into this question. The High Commissioner. I can assure him, has been most energetic in looking after Canadian interests. The High Commissoner, without the authority of the Canadian government endeavoured to have the embargo on Canadian cattle removed, and I am satisfied by tiie correspondence which has been produced here that he is still active in looking after Canada's interest.

Does the hon. gentleman (Mr. Hughes. Victoria) not know that the letter just read by the hon. member for Jacques Cartier (Mr. Monk) is dated the 18th

3S5S
of November ? How is it that the High Commissioner, who is looking after our business, did not know between the 30th June, 1901, and the 18th November, 1902, that the War Office was putting a condition into its contracts which would do harm to Canada ? Is he not there to look after our business ?

No, he is not there to look after contracts of that kind, or to conduct such business ; he is only there to carry out the instructions of the Canadian government. It is the duty of the hon. Minister of Agriculture here and his agents to see that the interests of Canada are properly guarded in all these respects. I merely rose to point out the fact that the High Commissioner seems to be the only person in London who has taken an active part in looking after Canada's interests in this matter.

THE FISHERY AWARD-STATEMENT BY THE PREMIER OF PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND.
speechtext:
Before you leave the Chair, Mr. Speaker, 1 desire to call the attention of the House and of the government to the budget speech delivered on the 10th of this month by the Prime Minister of Prince Edward Island, in which he spoke of certain negotiations now pending between the government of that province and the government of this Dominion with regard to claims toy that province upon what is known as the fishery award. I propose to read a portion of the speech of the premier of Prince Edward Island in which that reference is made. He was speaking of the taxation of his province, and he said :
We had in mind a plan of taxation which would practically remodel the whole existing system, but when we set about making up our estimates for the year, we found that the deficit woul be so small that it would be absurd to change the existing system of taxation in order to meet it. But not only that, I believe before the year 1902 closes, we will receive from Ottawa a sum which will be sufficient to carry on the affairs of this province without any additional taxation. We tnought it would be absurd to go to the expense and annoyance of putting extra taxes on the people, entailing a large expenditure in connection therewith, when we felt confident from advices from Ottawa that in a very short time our claims for our share of the Fishery Award would be recognized and paid. I am well aware that this has been flaunted, this little flag of truce has been held before the face of the electors of the province for a great number of years-that is true, but every thing has its day. We all know the story of the importunate widow.'
Then the Prime Minister of Prince Edward Island goes on to refer to certain claims heretofore made by the province upon tills government, and which claims were successfully made. I will not allude to these, as they are past transactions. The Prime Minister of Prince Edward Island continues, in his speech :
Thus was our persistence rewarded and so will it he with our Fishery Award. $4,000,000 of hard earned money was paid by the American government to the British government and by them paid to the Canadian government ; money earned by the sweat of the brow, by the toiling on the rowlocks of the boats of our island fishermen ; and by the terms of union and by the evidence given before the Halifax commission, we are entitled to our [DOT]share of that money. It has been claimed for years and now I am happy to say our hope is near fruition. Messrs. Farquharson and Mackinnon, who represent West and East Queen's in the House of Commons, have been pressing this claim, and Mr. BOURASSA.
I have communications not only from Mr. Mackinnon but also from the Department of Marine at Ottawa, which indicate that our claim has been so far admitted that the federal government is willing that it should be submitted to the Supreme Court of Canada for decision as to whether or not we are entitled to the amount. As to the result, any lawyer who has studied the question, the statute, and the evidence taken before the commission' will admit that we as well as Quebec, New Brunswick and Nova. Scotia, are entitled to the $4,000,000 ; and if it should have been ours in 1878, we are now clearly entitled also to the interest that the Dominion government has been putting into its .coffers for all these years down to date. They have been collecting interest on our $1,000,000 at 3 per cent, $30,000 per annum and have been paying back in fisheries bounties to this province the sum of $13,000. We will be entitled to receive at least $30,000 yearly interest, per annum, since confederation, in addition to our $1,000,000, and, Mr. Speaker, I feel all the more confident that our claim will be acknowledged since I find that the great province of Quebec, the pivotal province of. the Dominion, has taken the initiative and is now claiming her share of the award.
Now, Sir, in the King's speech at the opening of the session, we were told that this government had been negotiating with the Canadian Pacific Railway Company about a matter between the people of the Northwest and that company, and that the government had agreed to refer that matter to the Supreme Court. That was thought of sufficient importance to be communicated to this House in the speech from the Throne ; but although important negotiations affecting nearly $7,000,000-84,000,000 of principal and about $2,800,000 interest-although these negotiations have been pending with certain provinces, not one word has been communicated to parliament on this subject, and that, mark you, although the negotiations seem to have progressed so far that members of this House who are in communication with the government, have been able to inform the premier of Prince Edward Island that this claim is so far admitted! that the question will be submitted to the courts. Further than that, the government of Prince Edward Island seem to have had communications officially with the Minister of Marine upon this subject, and all this has been going on without the slightest word to this House. I do not know that I need make any extended remarks upon that question. It does seem to me a most extraordinary thing, that while this House is sitting and when we are only two weeks from the end of this session, we have not heard a word| on this subject from any of the ministers. I cannot believe that this statement of the premier of Prince Edward Island ds wholly without foundation. So certain is he of what he speaks, that he actually puts off the raising of necessary taxation in his province, because he believes that during this year and before another session this money will be paid, and it will not be necessary to raise that taxation, but that the province will be able

to pay its debts out of the money that is to be handed over by the Dominion government. I am not going to discuss the question as to whether the provinces are entitled to any portion of this award. I think it will be found that the people of this Dominion are not disposed to concede that this is not an asset of the Dominion at large. Whatever may be the case upon that point, what I contend for is this :	That
no such negotiations should have been carried on without our having knowledge of them in this House. I think, Sir, we are entitled to at least that much consideration. It is not merely that the province of Prince Edward Island is being led to expect the payment of this money, but probably Quebec, New Brunswick and Nova Scotia are expecting it as well. I suppose these are all importunate widows as the premier of Prince Edward Island calls them. We, therefore, have four importunate widows appealing to the government for this $4,000,000 principal and a quarter million dollars interest. Perhaps it would be good advice for :me to tender the Prime Minister to beware of the widows. However, that may be, if the right hon. gentleman's government is negotiating with them he should let us know it. I hope that the First Minister will be able to assure the House, that notwithstanding the positive language used by the premier of Prince Edward Island there is really no foundation for these expectations of his.

I have no fault to find with the spirit of the remarks of my hon. friend from Hamilton (Mr. Barker), and in view of the speech which has been delivered by the Prime Minister of Prince Edward Island, perhaps it would not be amiss if I should take this opportunity of altogether reassuring my hon. friend from Hamilton on the fears which he entertains that we may succumb to the blandishments of these several widows of whom he has spoken. I hope our virtue will be equal to the occasion, and that he will have nothing to fear upon that score. There has been loose talk, as my hon. friend knows for several years in the maritime provinces, and even in the province of Quebec :	That the award which
we obtained under the Washington treaty (which was not $4,000,000, but $4,500,000) should be distributed amongst the provinces. My hon. friend is aware that for a great many years past-almost since the time we received that award-we have been distributing, practically the interest on it in the shape of bounty to the fishermen; and whether the fishermen receive it from us or from the interested governments in the provinces in which they live, I do not know it would make very much difference. But there is another question which has occasioned a good deal of correspondence with, and remonstrances from the maritime provinces-indeed from all the provinces connected with fishery questions-and that is the foreshore question. A judgment was given three years ago by the Judicial Committee of the Privy Gouncil, which, unfortunately has left in doubt a good many questions with regard to the ownership of the foreshore. We have received communications from the several governments upon this point, and we have agreed to have a conference upon the whole subject. As to the distribution of the money which we have received under the fisheries award, though I am aware that claims have been made to us by several provinces, no decision has been arrived at. In fact, the subject has not been considered at all; and I may supplement what I say now by stating that at an early day the whole correspondence will be brought down, and then my hon. friend will know what action has been taken.
