Mr. LEFURGEY'. I have no objection whatever to make to the expenditure of $10,650 for improvements along the Prince Edward Island Railway, but I think the amount might well have been larger. I am in receipt of communications from different sources on the island, which point out a great many improvements that might be made, and for which I see no provision in the estimates. On the line between Cape Traverse and Emerald, there is not a booking station in that Whole length. The people of Kinkora, where there is quite a large settlement, have been asking for freight accommodation for some years, but so far have failed to obtain any satisfaction. In February last a large and influential meeting was held at Kinkora, and the following resolution unanimously adopted :
Moved by Rev. J. J. Macdonald, and seconded by Mr. John P. Smith :
Whereas up to the present, Kinkora has had insufficient railway station accommodations ; and whereas a cheese factory has been recently established, an agricultural implement factory is in operation, several merchants do a large import and export trade and the traffic on the railway here has about trebled itself within' the last three years.
And whereas a greater volume of business is transacted at Kinkora than at many localities along the main line where booking stations are now established.
And whereas there is every indication that in the near future there will be a large Increase Hon. Mr. BLAIR.
in the import and export trade of the community.
And whereas the government outlay necessary to establish proper station facilities will be more than compensated for by the consequent increased traffic.
And whereas great inconvenience and loss have been sustained for want of a proper station and for lack of telegraphic communication with business centres.
Be it therefore resolved that for the benefit of the railway itself, as well as for the interests of the community, this meeting recommends and urges the immediate erection by the government, of a suitable booking station at Kinkora crossing.
Further resolved, that a petition praying for sucl: railway facilities and for the appropriation necessary for that purpose, be circulated and presented to the government without delay, so that action may be taken thereon during the present session of the federal parliament.
These resolutions were passed at a large representative meeting and a petition forwarded to the government asking that the required improvements be made.
During the past season two merchants alone at Kinkora paid out $500 freight on their shipments, which of course is but a fraction of the general business done both in exports and imports. The train on this section leaves Cape Traverse about six o'clock in the morning, and the people exporting freight have to be out along the line about seven o'clock, in order to get it shipped, and as most of the shipping is done in the summer and the train has to wait for the boat, there is often no end of delay. The train frequently gets into Kinkora about two o'clock in the morning, so that the people there have to wait, up to receive their goods and the mail carrier has to sit up all night to receive the mail. And as the trains are not always on time, people have been known to wait hours in order to catch the train going out or coming back. There is only one train a day for passengers and freight. Besides the station for payment of freight is at Emerald, and goods are often held over until the merchant can go up to Emerald and pay his freight there. There is a large amount of business done in this section. As shown by the report, business has trebled there in the past three years. The business of the Prince Edward Island Railway during the past three years has increased- thus keeping pace with the general prosperity of the Dominion-some $50,000 over previous years, and there is every reason why the people of this vicinity should not be given railway accommodation at that point.
I may also say that the people of Kensington. a village which has grown considerably during the past few years, require increased freight accommodation. There is a large cheese and butter export from that section, and the superintendent of the company requires increased accommodation for the freight, and is anxious that the yard around the station should be put in proper repair. There are also several other sta-

tions along tlie line which are asking for improved accommodation. I am personally acquainted with the condition of affairs in Kinkora and Kensington, and I know that repairs and improvements are very much needed in these places. It seems to me that the hon. minister might well put in something more than $10,650 for improvements on the Prince Edward Island Railway, especially when the amount is charged to capital account. I would ask him to take this matter into consideration and not let another season pass without having this crying need of the people of Kinkora and Kensington for freight accommodation and booking stations supplied. I do not think it would cost over $3,000 or $4,000 to do the whole thing, and I have no doubt that the business of the. railway would benefit.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: I am quite ready to acknowledge that there is much in what the hon. gentleman has said with respect to the necessity of making improvements, at the earliest possible moment, along the line. It is not very long since I paid a personal visit to the island and traversed it on the railway, and I am free to acknowledge that there is quite a lot that should be done in order to give the people the facilities they need. I have not been allowed to lose sight of the importance of the question, because a number of members of parliament, among them my hon. friend from East Queen's (Mr. Mackinnon) and my hon. friend from West Queen's (Mr. Farquharson) and of King's (Mr. Hughes) have been urging upon me the importance of providing these improvements without delay. The necessity of having booking stations at Alberton, Fredericton and Kincora have been strongly impressed upon hie, and I shall be very glad to give all this matter the eraliest possible attention.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

Post office-Outside service-Salaries and allowances, $1,302,580.
['Certainly. Surely every hon. member of this House will endorse the position he takes, that if a man has a just claim he ought to be heard.\nSome resolutions reported.']
There is an increase here. Will the hon. Postmaster General please explain ?
There are a very large number of changes.

I notice that the letter carriers and mail delivery men have been pressing for an increase of salary, and I saw by a circular issued by them that something equivalent to a promise had been made by the minister that he would increase their salaries.

I suppose the hon. gentleman refers to the mail carriers. What is contemplated appears in the Bill before the House, which will be moved to a second reading at an early date. The hon. gentleman refers to an alleged promise of mine. 1 made no promise except to give the matter consideration, and that I have done.

In the Bill which the hon. gentleman has before the House I understand that the letter carriers are allowed to reach a salary of $600 in four years and a half instead of, as formerly, in nine years. But I understand that men who were appointed previous to 1896 are not receiving any consideration at the hands of the hon. gentleman in the Bill before the House.
Perhaps it would be more satisfactory if we discussed the Bill when it is up for its second reading. I will take the Bill up to-morrow if the hon. gentleman likes.
Is the minister making any provision for the appointment of an additional number of letter carriers in-Toronto, and if so, how many ?

There is no provision here for an increase in the number of letter carriers in Toronto, for the reason that certain changes are being made now in the Toronto service, and it is premature, therefore, to anticipate any necessity for an increased staff of letter carriers. At present the collection of letters is made by the staff, and it is intended to have that done by contract. There is a considerable number of men specially engaged in the collection of letters, and they will be relieved from that work and available to be transferred to the regular staff of letter carriers. Then we are erecting a station in the west end, at the corner of Queen and Abel streets, which I hope will be completed in the month of July. When it is completed it will simplify and Mr. SPEAKER.
expedite the work to be done in the west end. At j)resent mail matter for the west end arriving in Toronto has to be taken from the railway station to the city post office, there to be handled. By the methods now in view the mail matter will be taken from the railway station to this depot, and the carriers will have much shorter routes; they will start from this depot instead of, at present, as many of them do, from the central post office, or other places not so convenient. That will also have its effect. But until the system is in full operation it is not possible to say definitely whether any increase will be required in the numerical strength.
Will the automobiles now in use be taken over by the contractors, or be left in the hands of the department ?

They are on trial yet, and the trial, on the whole, is not satisfactory. One of the large machines answers fairly well. I do not want to say anything against the city, but I think the automobiles would be more satisfactory if the conditions were more favourable for their use. We hope there may be some change, and we are still hanging on to them.
Were they purchased by the Post Office Department ?
They were purchased, like all public property, by the Public Works Department. They are charged to public works, like public buildings.
That would be another item fairly chargeable to the Post Office Department that is not found in the accounts.

Before this item passes, I would like to ask the Postmaster General when he is likely to visit the west. We have had a good many ministers visiting there, but we have never had the Postmaster General visiting Winnipeg, and the cities of the west. It may be news to most hon. gentlemen here that the city of Winnipeg to-day is the third highest in post office receipts of any city in Canada. Last year $116,000 were received in revenue from the Winnipeg post office, and it is expected this year that the revenue will be $150,000 or $200,000; in fact, we will come very close to Toronto in a year or two. I want to suggest that the post office should be increased in size. The ground floor is very small, and when I came down this session I proposed to one or two of the ministers that a certain property could be bought at that time for about $750 to $S00 per foot. They laughed at the idea of buying pro-r-erty for $800 a foot. I want to tell the hon. gentleman that that property has since been sold for $850 per foot to an American firm, who expect to build a block upon it, and to make money

out of their investment. So the government was not very businesslike in that matter. Now, we are growing, our post office is growing and going to grow, and we want the ministers to grow up with it, and to realize what is going on. Our post office is a backwoods post office, the city of Winnipeg has to-day practically a backwoods post office. I have stood at the general wicket, and seen ten or fifteen people, on the average, waiting for one hour to get their mail, people who have no private boxes. The boxes are always taken up very quickly, and people have to wait at the general inquiry wicket; as I have said, I have seen ten or fifteen at a time waiting for an hour to get their mail. That is a condition of affairs that should not prevail in an up-to-date city. With regard to the distribution of the mail, why should we not have some such arrangement as Toronto, that the mail should be taken from the depot in an electric railway and distributed throughout the city by automobiles? It may surprise you to know that though, a few years ago, we were a muddy city, now we are building ten miles of streets per year, asphalted, at the expense of the city, the property is owned by the city. We are not doing that by contract, but by day labour. It is one of the most modern municipalities in Canada. Why will not the Postmaster General come up and see us, and see if he cannot increase the efficiency of the post office in the city of Winnipeg, see if he cannot give us some better facilities for getting our mail. A letter comes in there now and it is probably four or five hours before a business man receives it. That should not be permitted, it is not permitted in eastern cities. I cordially invite the Postmaster General to pay us a visit, and give us the benefit of his long experience, and try to help us out.
I would like the Postmaster General not to confine his visits to the west but come to the east also.
I say, stay where you are.

If the hon. Postmaster General will come to Montreal he will find, that, having regard to the proportionate population, we have, probably, there, the most unsuitable post office that there is in the Dominion.
Hear, hear.

If, as the hon. gentleman (Mr. McCreary) says, there is not sufficient accommodation in Winnipeg, it will be found that having regard to population the accommodation in Montreal is still more insufficient, and I believe, as we contribute such a large amount to the public revenue, we are entitled, in this respect, to some consideration. Those who are familiar with the conditions in Montreal know that the accommodation of the Dominion government in that city is altogether inadequate.
Hear, hear.

The Dominion government are obliged to pay a very considerable sum in rent in order to procure insufficient accommodation. I have in past years, urged, and I urge again on the attention of the government the fact that they would really economise considerably if they gave to the post office the dimensions that the post office should have, in view of the large population there is in Montreal, and by enlarging the building they could give the public the accommodation they are clearly entitled to above the post office-accommodation for the different departments of the public service that at present are obliged to pay a considerable amount of rental, representing certainly more than the capital which would be sufficient to place the post office on a decent footing.

While the hon. Postmaster General (Mr. Mulock) is on the eastern tack, I would invite him to come down to Charlottetown. Charlottetown is the capital of the province and in that city the post office is altogether inadequate to the wants of the people. It is small and it is dark. The hon. minister kindly consented to send an engineer down there, I understand; in fact, he has so informed me, and I hope we will hear something about it later. I hope the hon. minister will place an amount in the estimates about to be submitted for this purpose. However, I will say that we have been kindly treated, and I have to thank the hon. minister for any favours which we have received in regard to the post office. In fact, I think, we may have in some places too many post offices in Prince Edward Island. In our province it is very difficult to get suitable men to keep the post offices, because the remuneration is very small. I do not know whether there is any provision made for an increase in the remuneration or not. I believe that if it is not increased in the near future there will be many men who will give up their post offices, and the department will have to give them in charge of people who are not fit for the offices or who are located at inconvenient places. In Charlottetown we have no delivery system. That was suggested to me when I heard the hon. member for Toronto (Mr. Clarke). I do not know that we are asking for that, but if we do not get it, I think we should have an equivalent, a good post office in Charlottetown. Then again I would say a word in reference to the mail carriers in the country. I find that some of these men carry the mails for a mere nothing. As it is a matter of tender largely, I would say that it is their own fault, but I can assure the committee that there is no extravagance in connection with the mail service so far as Prince Edward Island is concerned. In reference to the officials in the post office and in other offices in the civil service, and I refer more particularly

now to the post office, I wish to say one word. I spoke here the other evening, and 1 now repeat what I then said, that I do not think it is fair that there should be the large discrepancy which does exist between the remuneration paid to different officials doing the same work. I have in my mind several good men that are in offices side by side with men who are no better than they are and not as good in some cases, because they entered the service at a different time, and under different conditions ; yet, some of these men draw $350 to $500 only a year, and the other $800 or $1,000, or $1,200, though doing the same work. 1 know all about this. There is something wrong which should be remedied. The law may be against the men who come in latterly. This is a condition which prevails under the laws and regulations as at present existing. Why should an official be the victim of some law that is perhaps an improper law? I consider that the law in these matters must be changed to meet the circumstances. You cannot get good men to go in under certain conditions at a salary of $400 or $500 a year. Wo have one young man in the post office at Charlottetown who, I think, will be six years in the service in July, lie is competent to perform the work of the post office. He gets, I think, $510, and there are others in the service geting $1,200. He is a better man than some others. I am not saying anything against the others, because they are very good men. I say this with all respect to the government and to the hon. Postmaster General, and I hope that there will be a redress of wrongs. I want to serve every one alike. I do not want to over pay a man, I do not want to under pay a man, but I want to see men paid in proportion to the work they perform. I would say: Get good men, and when you get them pay them fairly and see that they do their work. If the hon. Postmaster General does this, I believe that the people will stand by him. I consider that the law, as at present constituted, must be changed in order that these men shall receive justice at the hands of the government.

That the item be amended by adding, after the word ' allowances ' the following words : 'including J. W. Bain, post office inspector of the first-class in Montreal at $2,200, notwithstanding anything in the Civil Service Act.'
Amendment agreed to.

Who is Mr. Bain ? Is he a new appointee ?
Mr. Bain is a former member of this House, and was appointed hy the late government. He is a worthy officer and deserving of this.
Is this an additional employee beyond the number contemplated in the estimates ?

No.
The item was included but these words are necessary in compliance with the ruling of the Auditor General.
The minister told us that the automobiles were not proving satisfactory, but he did not tell us how many were purchased, and what they cost.

We
have had them for about three years now. My recollection is that there were six quad-rocyeles which are used for the collection of mail matter, and which I think cost about $000 each. There are I think two four-wheeled vehicles for carrying light loads between the post office and branches. There is also a large wagon capable of carrying probably a ton and a half which is in operation between the post office and the Union station. Of course I am only speaking from memory, as the contract was mado by the Public Works Department. I think the assistant postmaster for Toronto told me that these other machines cost in the neighbourhood of $1,500 each.
On what principle do you charge those to the Public Works Department ?

There is a mixing up of the departments in the public service. There is not the clear accounting between the departments that I think there ought to be. For instance, the Post Office Department renders a great many services that it gets no credit for, and perhaps in turn it may be a charge on other departments. The enormous amount of franking that goes on is not remunerative. During the recess, the different departments send an immense quantity of free mail matter, and the local governments have certain franking privileges as well. The Post Office Department is put to a large expense in connection with the savings banks which it carries on for the Finance Department, and which of course is not properly a matter of mail service, although it may very fittingly be done by the Post Office Department. There is no revenue from this, and the larger the savings the more it costs the Post Office Department to manage that service.
What difference does the Postmaster General make between paying contractors for carrying the mails all over the country, and this automobile service that he charges to the Public Works Department ?

I suppose the theory is that the Post Office Department does not own any property, and that the Public Works Department is supposed to own the buildings and everything else. The view of my hon. friend (Mr. Sproule) is perhaps more accurate, and if there was a strict accounting, everything used by the Post Office Department should
be charged against it and every service that is rendered by it to the other departments should be credited to it. However, that is not the way it has been done in the past. I do not know whether the country is prepared yet to do away with the "franking and other abuses: I consider them abuses to a certain extent. My hon. friend from Montreal (Mr. Monk) has referred to the post office building in that city; my hon. friend from Winnipeg (Mr. McCreary) has alluded to the Winnipeg building, and my hon. friend from Charlottetown (Mr. Far-quharson) draws the attention of the House to the inadequacy of the post office building at Charlottetown. I believe that all these objections are perhaps well taken, and it is gratifying in a sense to find that the increased volume of business under the policy of the administration is causing these public buildings to be inadequate for the demands upon them. I suppose that as fast as the circumstances of the countrv will admit, the Minister of Public Works will endeavour to enlarge these buildings so that they will meet the increased demands upon them. In all cases these buildings were in existence when we took office they have not been made smaller, but the business has outgrown the facilities afforded by them. My hon. friend (Mr. Farquharson) refers to inadequate salaries being paid, and lie cites a case in Charlottetown where one cleik.is receiving $500 a year and another cierk is receiving $1,200. I do not know whether the hon. gentleman desires me to accept as a standard every abuse that may * of,,;!!1 .pubIic service. It is perhaps a difficult thing to explain why one man do-mg the same kind of work as another, is paid a large salary and the other a much smaller one; but it happens that in our service men are promoted from the third to the second-class, and from the second-class to the first-class in process of time, without due regard at times to their efficiency or to the value of the service they lender. That is to be found in all branches of the service. When I took office, I may say by way of illustration, I found a clerk who was reported to me as engaged in doing nothing more than copying letters in a let-tei press, and I think the salary he received for that valuable service was $1,400 a year. That was an abuse of course, and yet if I employed a boy to do the work at $300 a year he would have complained that his mate was being paid four times as much. However, I would not think that that abuse should form a guide for our conduct. Abuses seem to be inseparable from the public service and in giving this illustration I am not reflecting on any person or on anv government.
It often happens that men grow old in the service and yet are not retired, though they are more or less unable to perform work, and light work is given to them. It 122
is a very pardonable weakness of human nature if we are kindly disposed towards those who have grown old and infirm ; but all the same, in view of a debate which took place in this House a short time ago, I am afraid that parliament would not approve of an increase of the salary list of the Charlottetown post office just now. I think tile hon. member for West Hastings (Mr Porter) pointed out that the amount being paid by way of salaries in the Charlottetown post office was very greatly out of proportion to what was being paid in other parts of the Dominion.

Before this item passes, I would like to get a promise from the minister that he will give us an electric service in Winnipeg from the station to the post office the same as there is in Ottawa, a city which contributes less -revenue to the Post Office Department than the city of Winnipeg a!so that he will provide automobiles to collect the mall matter throughout the city.

The hon gentleman knows that I could not promise anything involving public expenditure without obtaining the permission of the government and the assent of His Excellency, because that would involve a vote ; but I will promise this, which is all he can expect from me, that I will give the matter my best consideration. As to putting the mails on a tramway between the station and the post office, I will promise to give that consideration too ; and if it is reported to be a better plan than the one that exists now, and we can make fair terms for the service, we will adopt the improvement. We are always ready to adopt an improvement if we can make proper terms. As to adopting automobiles in Winnipeg, I would not care to promise it at present, because we are testing them. They have only gone through one winter, and the test up to date is not satisfactory.
It is said that they are most of the time iu the blacksmith's shop being repaired.
It is very much that way.

I think I might come to the rescue of the Postmaster General at this stage. He has been requested by hon. members to visit Winnipeg, Montreal and Charlottetown, in order that he may see for himself the very poor facilities which are provided in the post offices of these cities. In Toronto we enjoy the distinction, I may say the honour, of having the Postmaster General with us all the time, and I must take issue with my hon. friend from Jacques Cartier (Mr. Monk) when he says that Montreal has the most unsuitable post office in proportion to population in tne Dominion.
I venture to say that we have in Toronto



the most unsuitable post office in the Dominion in proportion to the amount of business done. Perhaps when only half the business was done that we are now doing, it might have been considered satisfactory ; but at present it is most unsatisfactory. The Postmaster General informed us to-night, as I think he has done on previous occasions, that it was the intention to build branch post offices-one at the corner of Queen and Abell streets, and perhaps others at other points. But it would be a great credit to the country and the city to have a fine post office building, and I hope the government are not shirking the responsibility they should assume in the way of erecting a respectable post office building in the city of Toronto, a city which I understand pays the largest revenue to the Post Office Department of any city in the Dominion. If the system is carried out of having these branch post offices, I suppose the mail will have to be assorted at the Union Station.
On the train.

I do not understand the system sufficiently to discuss that feature ; but I hope that we shall not be side-tracked in Toronto in the ambition to have a fine public building in the shape of a post office, such as the Dominion will have good reason to be proud of.
I would like to ask the lion. Postmaster General whether the postmaster for Holstein in the south riding of Grey has been dismissed, and if so, for what reason ?
I cannot say from memory, but I will mane inquiries and tell the hon. gentleman tomorrow.

I wish to say a word or two about the small salaries paid the country postmasters throughout the province of Ontario. There is a very universal complaint on this subject among the postmasters and farmers in the rural districts of the western part of the province. As the hon. Postmaster General will understand, a different condition of things prevails among the farmers now from what there was several years ago. The farmers are now engaged in supplying the larger cities with dairy produce, such as butter, milk and cream, and they require a better postal service than they did many years ago when they were engaged in growing grain. The country postmasters are really very poorly paid. In many instances in the county which I have the honour to represent the patrons of country post offices are compelled to contribute money privately in order to get a proper service. It is all very well for the hon. minister to talk about the large and increasing revenue, and I am very glad he has the privilege of talking

that way ; and it is all very well for the city members to ask for larger post office buildings. I am not complaining of that; but I say that in my humble opinion there is no class of employees of the Post Office Department of Canada who are so poorly paid as the postmasters in the rural districts. If ever there was an opportunity for the Postmaster General to comply with the demands of the country people in that respect, surely it is now, when the revenue is so large ; because there will come a time,
I have no doubt, when the revenue will not be so large. I am sure that I speak the sentiments of the members on both sides of the House when I say that in this prosperous time some special provision should be made for paying country postmasters a sufficient salary for the work they are called on to perform.

1 listened to the hon. member for Selkirk (Mr. McCreary) when he was speaking for better postal facilities in the city of Winnipeg. I was rather surprised to hear that hon. gentleman ask for such an expenditure as would be necessary to provide the accommodation he desires, when we remember that the Postmaster General is extremely anxious to make his department self-sustaining, and also that our friend from the North-west is always prepared to talk free trade and to deprive the country of that revenue from customs imports which is necessary to supplement the postal revenue and to provide the accommodation he desires. The hon. gentlemen who do not want to contribute to the revenue of the country should not be so exacting upon the Postmaster General or any other minister for increased expenditure. While on my feet I desire to ask a question of the Postmaster General in reference to a matter which came up the other evening in connection with the Customs Department ; that is, how postmasters provide their sureties. I understand that the plan adopted by the Postmaster General is to have the government bond all the postmasters and the other officers of the department, instead of paying a guarantee company a certain sum of money or compelling the postmasters to pay a certain sum for their guarantee. I am under the impression that this is a wise movement. I understand that the postmasters are now guaranteed for about two-thirds of what they were guaranteed before by the Guarantee Company, and I am under the impression still that that could be even cut in two and yet leave a sufficient sum to meet all the default cases likely to occur in the Post Office Department. I would like the Postmaster General to go a little further along this line, and he would then be assisting men, who are underpaid, by enabling them to contribute less for their guarantee. I understand that that has been the practice for one or two years, and I hope that it will be extended.

There is another matter I would ask the hon. gentleman about. I am told that a letter posted at Toronto Junction, which is a separate post office, requires only a cent stamp to carry it to Toronto, but to carry a letter from the city of Toronto to Toronto Junction requires 2 cents. It seems to me that that is an anomaly.

The condition to which the hon. gentleman refers did exist with regard to the mail service between a number of the villages around Toronto and Toronto itself, but I put an end to it when it was brought to my attention some two or three years ago.

I thought that if it extended to villages around Toronto, say five miles out, there was no reason why it should not extend 35 miles out, and include the village I am living in. I am glad to hear that we are all put on the same footing. I would like to hear from the hon. gentleman what he proposes to do with reference to guarantees.

When I took office I found that the only system in vogue was a separate guarantee bond for each official. These bonds lasted a year, and it was quite a task to keep track of them, and also to get the bonds taken out in the first instance. I got parliament to authorize the establishment of an assessment system in the service itself, but did not transfer to that system all the insurance of every officer, but only a portion. By degrees, however, the system has been extended, and by the 30th June next we will cease taking the bonds of any guarantee company at all. A^, regards the postmasters, where the revenue of the office is $200 or less, it is optional with them to furnish a private bond or to subscribe to the assessment system, in which latter case they will have to pay 40 cents per $100 or 80 cents for the $200. We may practically consider that the whole service is now under the system with the exception of postmasters, the revenue of whose offices is $200 and under, and it is optional with them to join the system or not.
Then, the government practically bond their officers without reference to any guarantee company.

At the end of the fiscal year the majority of the officers will be furnishing insurance on the assessment system. Some of the higher officers, who have to furnish a larger amount of security, are partly insured in the assessment system and partly in the guarantee company.
What do you think should be the load of a letter carrier ?

That would depend upon the size of the man, and I do not know what the weight should be, but the letter carriers are pretty heavily la'den down, especially on the first delivery. As a matter of fact, they cannot complete their delivery in the time they were able to do it formerly. Merchants are compelled to have the letters brought by special messengers of their own rather than wait until the letter carrier reaches them. In some instances, the first delivery does not reach them until nine or ten o'clock. It is false economy not to employ a sufficient number of men to do the work promptly. It seems to me that if the hon. minister has the time to spare he should look into the situation, so far as the distribution is concerned in the city of Toronto.
I do not want to worry the hon. gentleman but would like to know what has become of the branch post offices. They appear to have dropped out of existence. We require pretty sharp eyes to find them out. We had several of them, and I believe the deputy postmasters received salaries equi-valentLto $500 or $600 a year, but their services have been dispensed with and others appointed on salaries from $100 to $200 a year. And instead of being in commodious, suitable places, these branch offices have been transferred, in many instances, to small places you can hardly find. Why was the change made? Was it to effect a saving in Ihe salaries? Was any complaint made as to the inefficiency of the men in this branch of the service ? Were they not discharging their duties satisfactorily? Or was the sole idea of dispensing with the services of these men and appointing others the saving of three or four hundred dollars a year in each case? The complaint, as the Postmaster General knows, was very general with re-

spect to the change of these branch post offices in Toronto. Complaints were made by friends of the hon. gentlemen opposite, as well as by those who are not so friendly, against the dismissal of these men, and the removal of their offices from their various locations.

As to the last Inquiry, of what had become of the branch post offiees ?	1 would say
that the branch post offiees Were found to be largely engaged in so-called work which was not only useless, but was really an obstruction to the public service. Though the system of collection and delivery by special messengers existed in the city, yet some twenty or thirty branch post offices had been established to which people could go and post their letters, the branch postmaster taking possession of them, stamping them and tying them in bundles to be taken to the city post office, where the parcels had to be untied, and the letters re-stamped. This meant a wholly unnecessary handling of the letters. Experience has shown that the more hands letters pass through, the less security there is, as a rule. A recognized part of good management of a postal system is to have letters pass through as few hands as possible. It was considered in the public interest, as being more expeditious, not to have the letters pass into the hands of the branch postmasters but to have them taken from the ordinary receptacles by the collector and carried at once to the central office. With this change, the work of handling the letters was taken from the branch postmasters. The remaining portion of the work is of a comparatively trifling character. These should not be called branch post offices, because they are not such in the ordinary sense; the term is a misleading one. They sell postage stamps-which are to be found on sale in hundreds of places throughout the city-they receive registered letters and issue postal notes and money orders. That is about the extent of the work in these institutions.

I tried to follow the hon. Postmaster General closely. If I understand him, the letters instead of being posted in the branch post offices are posted in the pillars outside. But the letters have still to be collected from these receptacles as they were before, and there are as many collectors as there were before. I take it that the only difference in the work done by the branch postmasters is that they do not have to stamp the letters and send them to the general office.

That was nine-tenths of their work-the handling of the letters. The public would hand letters to them, and the branch postmasters would act as postmasters and make up a mail on the central office. That was a wholly unnecessary procedure. We have
many letter boxes in Toronto and the letters dropped into them are simply taken by the collectors to the general office where they are stamped, and this one handling is sufficient.

All these branch post offices were supplied with letter boxes. Parties going in to buy stamps handed their letters to postmasters or dropped them into the boxes. Now, I understand,i they must go outside to drop the letter in the pillar outside the branch post office.

The ordinary boxes on the highway. My hon. friend knows that when they were dropped in the branch post office they were practically in the custody of the branch postmaster and were handled by him. That is not the case now-he cannot touch them. The letters go direct from the letter boxes through the bag of the collector, to the post office. They are not handled by the branch postmaster, and that unnecessary handling is dispensed with.

Is there an additional collection made from the pillars or large receptacles outside the branch post offices now as compared with the number of collections made before the branch post offices were dispensed with ?

I cannot tell whether there has been an increase in the frequency of the collections. The practical working of the post office in Toronto is left in the hands of the staff there, and I do not think the hon. gentleman can expect me to tell him how many times a day these boxes are visited. I believe the boxes are visited frequently-I think more frequently thifn before. The hon. gentleman shakes his head, but I am sure he will not contradict what I say.
As the Postmaster General said he did not know anything about it, I thought! that perhaps
I am sure there has been no reduction in the frequency of collections.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: In the amount that the Postmaster General has asked the House to vote, has he made provision for the reopening of the post office at Marble Rock, a post office established some thirty years ago.
Where is it ?

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Seven miles from Gan-anoque. A petition was presented to the Postmaster General not very long since, signed by over a hundred persons who received or would receive their mail at that office.

I will make a note of the inquiry and will be able-

to give my hon. friend the answer tomorrow.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: Very well. 1 desire also to call the attention of the Postmaster General to what I consider an abuse of the postal service-the post office practically doing an express office business. Large departmental stores, as I understand, get the voters' lists of the various municipalities throughout the province, and to the names upon these lists they send catalogues. In response to a letter they will send a full set of samples of dry goods or to other articles, which they can send for a few cents. People make their selection, send their money and get the goods back by mail. This is a great injury to the country storekeeper, and, as I say amounts to the post office doing an express office business. A large portion of the mail now is made up of dry goods and other merchandise. The mails should be exclusively for mail matter and the post offices should not be the means of carrying on a retail and wholesale dry goods business.

That is a very proper subject for consideration. But perhaps my hon. friend would not find public opinion at his back if he proposed to restrict the mails entirely to correspondence. That is not the practice either in the United Kingdom or in the United States. I do not know when the parcel system was inaugurated in Canada, but it was many years ago, and no change has been made in any respect since the present government took office. The abuse my hon. friend refers to has existed for many years. I do not remember having heard him take this point earlier. I doubt very much if public opinion would support us in refusing to allow small parcels to be sent through the mails. That would be a very sweeping change. A person can send a small parcel through the post office for a couple of cents, which he would have to pay 25 cents to send by an express company.

Referring to the question of wages brought up a few minutes ago by the hon. member for Prince Edward Island (Mr. Farquharson), I would suggest to the Postmaster General a change in the basis of paying for carrying the mails. At present in many country districts the mail is carried on horseback or with a vehicle, and I think the hon. gentleman would do well to pay so much per mile instead of as at present, paying a fixed price. Sometimes the mail carriage is given out by tender and sometimes it is not. When it is not given out by tender, of course the friends of the government get it, and when it is given by tender they have some other way of getting it. I remember the Postmaster General said five years ago in this House that all mail should be carried by public tender, he said he was going to do so, but he has not fulfilled his promise. He still keeps up
the system of giving that work to the friends of the government. I know one of his friends who is carrying the mail a distance of 26 miles, and it takes the whole day to make the trip back and forth, on a very bad road, and that man only gets $270 a year. He gets a starving price, a bankrupt price to carry that mail. I say, give him a little more, and let the man live. I know another place where the mail carrier carries the mail 6 miles. He leaves home in the morning about 9 o'clock and comes back in the afternoon at 5 o'clock. He has a horse and wagon, and that man gets $90 a year. How can a man live at such a price, maintain his horse, and keep up his wagon or sleigh for $90 a year ? At another place a man carries the mail 13 miles, or 26 miles the round trip. He leaves home in the morning at about 7 o'clock and gets back at 8 or 9 in the evening, by very rough roads. The Postmaster General should establish a price of so much per mile, as he gives railway companies so much per pound.

I am afraid that mileage system would hardly work. The law says that we shall give out the contracts, and award them to the lowest tenderer. When men tender I cannot go and increase the tender price for them. . If I did so, I think my hon. friend would very likely take exception to it. As to adopting the mileage system, it is to be borne in mind that many mail carriers do the business of carrying parcels and passengers as well as the mails. There are other districts, perhaps, which do not afford any such advantages.
That is all right, but I would advise the hon. gentleman to do as he has been doing. The law says that he shall do one thing, and he does another, and so he could in reference to these mail carriers.
I would like to ask the Postmaster General whether the Morris street branch at Halifax has been closed, and if so, for what reason ?
I am informed it has been discontinued as a branch office, and will be opened out shortly as a sub-office.
What is the distinction between a branch office and a sub-office ?

Under the old system a branch office was, or might be, an independent post office. Mail matter was posted there and handled by the postmaster, and if people in the vicinity chose to go there they could get their letters. We have discontinued generally throughout Canada the system of branch offices, and are applying the free delivery system.
Will the public at these sub-offices be enabled to transact business in the same way as at the post office ? For example, can they get money orders ?
Yes, they can buy postage stamps, money orders and postal notes, and deliver registered letters and get receipts for them, and do savings bank business.
At how early a date is it expected that office will be opened ?
At once, you may look for it daily.
Can the Postmaster General inform me what salaries were paid to branch postmasters prior to the 31st of December last, and what salaries are paid now?

I have not had the fixing of salaries before the 1st of January. There was an arbitrary sum being paid, that was not based upon any rule that I could discover. I suppose it was dependent on the amount of influence the postmasters had. As to the present system, a general scale of remuneration has been adopted, and a printed tariff; and keepers of'branch post offices were furnished with a copy of the terms upon which they could continue as keepers of the sub-offices. In most cases they have elected to continue on as keepers of the sub-offices.
What salaries were paid to keepers of these branch offices prior to the change referred to; what was the smallest salary paid under the old method ?

As I have said, there was no fixed salary. They were paid varying sums. The hon. gentleman will find in the report of the Postmaster General, that in the city of Toronto, sums were paid varying from $200 to $800 or $900. They are now paid according to a regular scale applicable to all.
Would it be possible to get the information from the hon. Postmaster General now. Could he say how much he is paying now ?

There is a minimum allowance, by way of gratuity, for postmasters of $60. A postmaster is also paid one per cent upon the postage stamp sales, he is also paid a commission upon the sales of money orders and postal notes and a commission of one-quarter percent on the receipt of deposits.
His salary, or gratuity, is $60 a year ?

He receives a gratuity of from $60 to $100. One Hon. Mr. MULOCK.
hundred dollars is the maximum of the allowance which covers any special inconvenience he may be put to. He also receives a commission on certain classes of business.

Has the person who has charge of the branch office to pay the rent of the building and give attendance, to issue money orders, registered letters and receive deposits for this amount ? Is he called upon to provide a suitable place and to pay the rent for which he receives $100 remuneration and a commission amounting to $50 or $100 ?

We do not employ persons who are not engaged in business as the keepers of sub offices. The sub offices are placed, as a rule, in charge of druggists and stationers. This does not involve an,increased size of building, extra equipment, or staff. The amount of business done at a sub" office is comparatively trifling and the keeper probably makes no addition to his expenses.

We, in the city of Winnipeg, for a couple of years have had these sub post offices. I remember that at the time the Board of Trade of Winnipeg and I first applied to the hon. Postmaster General for branch post offices such as they had in the city of Toronto, the hon. Postmaster General pointed out the serious drawbacks he had found in the department when operating these branch offices. He established five or six sub offices which have proved of great benefit. The public appreciate them very much. As far as we are concerned, as the city extends, we shall apply for more sub post offices. The people who keep these sub offices get very little for it. They admit that. I am doubtful if it actually pays the expenses but I notice that these offices are always given to tradesmen, that there is keen competition for them and I am also aware of the fact that they hang on to them so closely that it is hard even to change a location. I have been impressed with the idea that the system of sub post offices is the best system to operate. I would like to ask the hon. minister, in cities where there is a letter carrier service, is there any basis of apportioning the number of carriers according to the population. Is there any approximate relation between the population and the number of carriers that a city is allowed ?

No, the number of carriers is increased from time to time in accordance with the local demands. The officers in a city, report that they require additional assistance and that becomes the foundation for increases. The volume of business would not be the only basis because it is sometimes more difficult to serve one city than another. One city may extend over a greater area than another, or

one city may be more difficult to serve. Take the city of Quebec, for instance. Therefore, the volume of business, although it has a material influence, is not the only determining factor.

Having reference to the complaint of the hon. member for West Toronto (Mr. Clarke) that there were not enough letter carriers in Toronto, which is probably correct, I want to state that I have looked through the civil service list and I have found that Toronto has 140 carriers and that in Winnipeg, according to the Civil Service list, there are only eighteen. Our population at the last census, and the actual population is greater than the census population, was over 44,000, which would give us one carrier to every 2,400 of the population. Upon that same basis Toronto would have a population of over 300,000. Whatever may be the position of affairs in Toronto we are exactly in the position that has been brought to the attention of the hon. Postmaster General by the hon. member for Selkirk (Mr. McCreary) that we cannot get any of the public services in the west to extend as rapidly as business and population increase. I have had great trouble and the postmaster in Winnipeg has had trouble to impress upon the post office department that there is need of a steady increase of the staff there. Two years ago when this matter was brought before the post office authorities it was not nearly^ so pressing as it is now. It was almost impossible then to conceive that the business which is being done to-day could be done without more accommodation and without an increase in the staff. I imagine that the business has increased more than fifty per cent. We have still only eighteen letter carriers. As a matter of fact there are some temporary men, as I presume there are in Toronto, but our city covers a large amount of ground, it is not an easy city for a letter carrier service and yet we have that limited number of carriers.

Mr. Chairman, I did not understand from the Postmaster General whether the system which he intended to adopt in Toronto of having district post offices was a system which would be adopted generally in places where the business has increased. Is it intended to have a similar system in Montreal to that which it is proposed to establish in Toronto ; for instance, the system of having a post office in the west end at the corner of Queen and Abel streets, because of the inadequacy of the present post office ? Then, before he answers that question, I would like to ask him another. He said that he intends to sort letters for the western post office on the trains. Does he intend to divide the city up into districts numbered 1, 2 and 3, or A, B and C, and is it possible to have a staff of clerks on the trains coming in from all directions to handle the mail matter intended for district offices. Is this to be a general policy or is it to be a policy just for Toronto ? Is it intended to extend this policy and have other district post offices ? Is it the policy of the hon. gentleman to have more than one, or two or three post offices in large centres ?

As far as Toronto is concerned it is found that tlie post office now is not central. It is too far to the east. My hon. friend (Mr. Kemp) is familiar with the locality. It lias been found that there is a loss of time in the transfer of the mails from the station to the eastern part of the city in which the post office is situated; that is of those mails which are intended for the west. In like manner there is an unnecessary delay in transferring the mail matter from the west end to the station if it it has to go around bv the post office. By cutting off the Toronto post office from the route to be taken the mail matter which will come in by rail will arrive at station C in the west end much more quickly and we will be able to close the outgoing mails from the west much later. That office has been decided upon as the outcome of the situation there. It is in contemplation as well to have at least one more in the northerly part and perhaps one. or two coming around towards the east, but we cannot do it all at once. This one office will be equipped and I hope in working order towards the middle of July and my hope is that next year I will be permitted by parliament to make provision for another station at the next most convenient place in Toronto. As to Montreal, simultaneously with the arrangements being made for the establishment of a west end office in Toronto it was decided to inaugurate the system in Montreal by having a similar station in that city. The Minister of Public Works (Hon. Mr. Tarte) is in charge of the matter and I think has been negotiating for the selection of a suitable place as a site for it. I do not know whether there will be provision made in the estimates but that will appear when they come down. But Montreal is as much in need of a station as is Toronto, and I hope it will have one in the near future. The hon. gentleman asked me what the system of sorting it. The heaviest mails come in from the east arriving by the morning trains, and in order to enable these letters to go out on the first delivery in the morning, officers are sent down the night before by the night train to meet the upcoming train and to sort the letters for the letter carriers. That enables the letters to go out on the first delivery instead of on the second delivery as formerly. That is not yet necessary on the westerly trains, but should it be necessary that system will be adopted also.

I do not think that it is the practice in the United States to have so

many different post offices in cities of the population of Montreal ana Toronto. I presume that the Postmaster General has given this matter a great deal of consideration, and I will have to bow to his decision, but it strikes me at first glance that the better system would be to have one central post office. If the Toronto post office is not now in the centre of the city according as the population has grown of late years, would it not be better to sell that property and build a large post office that would be a credit to the country, near the present centre of population, rather than to have so many small post offices scattered in different places. Has the Postmaster General considered the Question of this American advertising matter which comes through the post office at very low rates. I see the letter carriers bags overburdened with this useless matter, and I would like to know if it is carried at a less rate of postage in the United States than would be charged in Canada ?	[DOT]
The newspaper rate in the United States is 100 per cent higher than in Canada.
These are not newspapers, but large cards printed on one side with the address on the other.

These would probably pass in the United States as post cards, which have the same rate here as in the United States, and according to the international arrangement, mail matter posted in the United States and directed to Canada must be delivered for the rate prevailing in the country of origin.
What is the policy of the government as to branch post offices ?

These are the outgrowth of necessity, and when the conditions demand it an additional station is erected. The letter carriers for the districts assemble at these stations, and a great deal of time is saved by them in not having to go to the central post office and return to their beats. I think my hon. friend will see the wisdom of that feature.
Experiments have been made in the United States in regard to rural delivery. Has the Postmaster General considered the application of that system to Canada ?

I sent Mr. George Ross, assistant postmaster at Toronto, to the United States to study the system, and he was of opinion that it was not adaptable to Canada, which is a country of vast distances and rather sparse settlement. I do not think that the taxpayers of Canada would for a moment consent to the great expense which would be involved. Moreover, there is a very divided opinion as to its benefits in the rural dis-Mr. KEMP.
tricts of the United States, the contention being that the post office is used by farmers and others for the purchase of goods from larger cities, and the local merchants are not patronized as they were before. The system is not at all popular in some districts in the United States.

I am afraid I will have to withdraw my invitation to the Postmaster General to come to Montreal, because 1 notice that in Toronto, where he lives, the same abuses exist as in Montreal; but in Winnipeg, where the Postmaster General has not been, the conditions seem to be better. Perhaps living is more expensive in Winnipeg, but at all events the letter carriers are comparatively adequately paid.
We are not satisfied.

It shows how these western people are difficult to satisfy. The smallness of the salaries paid to the letter carriers in Montreal and Toronto is a very real grievance.
Hon. Mr. ROSS (Victoria, N.S.) So it is everywhere.

Surely not where the hon. gentleman lives; living must be very cheap down there.
Hon. Mr. ROSS (Victoria, N.S.) I live in Halifax.

I find that in Winnipeg the majority of the letter carriers get a salary of $720 a year. The salaries of the letter carriers in Montreal are much too low. There is no sense in it at all; they are almost as bad as the salaries of our judges. In Montreal, I say, the delivery is not satisfactory, because I think the letter carriers are very badly organized, very poorly paid. The delivery is not what it should be in a large city. I have been in other cities where you couid drop a letter in the box, and tell to the hour almost when it would reach its destination. It is not so in Montreal by any means. You find letter carriers in Montreal getting $365, $390, $358, $367, $382, $308.
There is no officer getting $308.	'
Here it is in the public accounts.
Not; for a year's work.
Yes, to be exact, $308.71 for a year's work. The man's name is Pacific, and the hon. Postmaster General must admit that he has to be very pacific indeed to live on that.
Is that the highest ?

No, there are some who receive $600-why ? Does the one who gets $308 not deliver as much as the others ? I say the salary is inadequate and the system is bad. It is a cause of complaint in

Montreal among a large class. I do not say that the Postmaster General should come there, because his residence in Toronto does not seem to have improved matters; but he should send down some one who can give us a remedy.

Before the item is adopted, X would like the minister to make some statement in reference to the salaries paid to country postmasters, and as to whether the government are prepared to make any proposition to the House for paying them better ?

The salaries paid to the country postmasters are in accordance with a scale adopted by my predecessor's in office. They maintained that scale for eighteen years, with the approval of the country, and I suppose also of my hon. friends who are now in opposition: and they have not yet explained to this House any changed circumstances which would call for a reduction of those rates.
The growing times.

I may say that there are a great many small post offices where the postmasters receive the whole revenue and more too. Post offices are found dotted all over the country-almost too close to each other, as my hon. friend from Queen's, P.E.I. stated a little while ago. Does my hon. friend from Peel (Mr. Blain) propose that a person who keeps a post office the gross revenue of which is only $10 or $15 a year, shall be paid more than $15 ? In many cases the postmaster himself is the chief gainer, because he has the mails brought to his house instead of having to go for them to a post office a mile or so away. If the public insists on post offices being so close together, there must be small salaries paid. In reality, these alre only nominal allowances, the offices themselves doing a merely nominal business.
Would the hon. minister state about what the average pay of a country postmaster is in the western part of Ontario ?

The pay is based on the revenue of the office. Up to a revenue of $800 the postmaster receives 40 per cent of the gross receipts. He also gets some small commissions on money orders, postal notes and savings bank business; but these make a rather trifling amount. When the revenue is in excess of $800 and up to $10,000, he gets 25 per cent on the excess ; and if it is over $10,000 he is paid 15 per cent on the excess.
offices which have been opened perhaps for the convenience of half a dozen people, the postmaster being the chief beneficiary. These offices are only doing a nominal post office business, perhaps averaging only a letter a, day, and the postmasters are paid a nominal fee. That has been the invariable practice in Canada, and I presume it will continue for all time. I do not know what my hon. friend's idea would be for paying postmasters. You could not, I suppose, offer a man a lower salary then say $100 a year. At that rate you would pay $1,000 postmasters $100,000, while the revenue from their offices would perhaps be only $10,000. I do not think the country would justify our opening those offices on such conditions.

I am sure that the Postmaster General's statement will not be satisfactory to the farming community of the province of Ontario. It is all very well for tlie minister to say that he found a certain state of things existing when he came into office. I would remind him that he has been making many changes, some of which have been approved of by the people of Canada; but many of his changes have been in the direction of benefiting the cities almost exclusively. Who gets the greatest benefit of the reduction of the postage from 3 cents to 2 cents ? Is it not the banking institutions, the large loan companies, the merchants and manufacturers of this country ? These are the people who have been getting the chief advantage of the changes which the hon. minister has made. If it is true, as I think it is, that in some parts of Ontario there are too many post offices, that is a matter that ought to concern the hon. minister himself, and he should give it some consideration. If there are too many, he should reduce the number and equip the offices, and pay the postmasters proper salaries. The farmers in Ontario are now engaged in a different kind of work from what they were engaged in twenty years ago. They are supplying butter and small produce to the larger cities, and for that reason require to go to the post office every day for their mail matter. Therefore, the minister should seriously consider the advisability of re-adjusting the condition of things in the country districts, so that the farmers may have a better service, and not be called upon to contribute a special amount to the country postmasters, as they are in many parts of Ontario at present. No doubt the hon. minister has been considering this question, but what I complain about is his want of action in giving the farmers better mail service in the province of Ontario.
>Is it not a fact that there are a large number of postmasters in country districts who get salaries ranging' from $10 to $25 a year ?
There are hundreds, perhaps thousands of small

My hon. friend complains that we are doing more for the cities and less for the rural districts, but he will only have to wait a few minutes to hear a different story from the representatives of the cities. He suggests that there

should be a reduction in the number of post offices and larger salaries paid the postmasters remaining. Would the hon. gentleman like me to give any attention to the county of Peel and reduce the number of post offices there ? Would it be far more satisfactory to the farmers of Peel to drive a longer distance for them mails than they do now and pay higher salaries to the postmasters. It may be that in the hon. gentleman's county the farmers are so philanthropic that they believe that the offices exist for the benefit of the postmasters. Elsewhere, however, the idea prevails that these offices exist for the general public. Surely the hon. gentleman is not serious when he proposes a reduction in the number of post offices. He may rest easy, however, in his mind as regards the county of Peel, for I do not purpose to close any of the post offices there or elsewhere. Let me tell the hon. gentleman that I do not believe he could get any of the people to consent to the closing up of one office out of a thousand in the whole Dominion, however, unnecessary these offices might be. Once post offices are established and the people have become accustomed to them, they insist on their being kept open. I have had not only to open up new offices but to carry on those which were established by the late government, even in places where perhaps they were not actually required. There has been no such serious change in the mode of carrying on business to-day as calls for a greater increase in the number of post offices in close proximity than existed five years ago in the rural districts. I am quite as familiar with the methods of doing business in the rural districts as my hon. friend, and with the conditions in Ontario, and I think that the farmers are in favour of a multiplicity of small offices. When a man, for his own sake, or that of his neighbours allows his farm house on the road side to be used as a post office, he does not, as a rule, expect any substantial remuneration, although quite willing to take it should it come his way.
Let me remind the hon. minister that he has already given some consideration to the county of Peel by cutting off the heads of some of the postmasters in that county.
I did hot close the offices.

No, but the hon. gentleman cut some of their heads off, without any complaint being made against the postmasters at all. He need not therefore expect to create any apprehension by saying that he might bring further consideration to the county of Peel. No doubt he will do that in any case, in the general conduct of his business. I am quite sure that the hon. gentleman did not wish to misquote me. I did not say that the post offices should be reduced in Ontario.
You argued that way.

I beg the hon. gentleman's pardon. What I did say is that the question should get the consideration of the minister, and if he found that there were too many post offices in the province of Ontario, it would be his duty to reduce the number.

I am quite satisfied that there are too many, and I am perfectly satisfied that if I took the hon. gentleman's own riding I would find too many there. Would he wish me to close any of the post offices in that county because I thought there were too many.

I might tell the hon. minister that he could begin with his own county. I had a drive through his county a short time ago, and the gentleman who accompanied me pointed out where the hon. minister had opened up several post offices in North York, for some very peculiar reasons which I will not weary the House with at present. When the hon. gentleman says I am not in earnest, I wish to correct him. I am in earnest, and I might remind him that many of his own supporters in the county of Peel have written me complaining of the condition of things, complaining that the minister gives special consideration to the large manufacturing establishments and the large financial and banking institutions, but does not give the same consideration to the farmers by furnishing them with a proper postal service in the province of Ontario. Let the hon. gentleman come to the county of Peel if he wishes, and make such arrangements as will bring about a better system of postal service for the people of that county, and I will be very glad to give him what assistance I can. But I would like him to see that there are no postmasters who work twelve months in the year and only get from $10 to $14 for their services.

The hon. gentleman complains that the reduction in postage favours certain classes and not others. He has argued that that reduction inures only to the benefit of the large banking establishments and manufacturers, but that the farmers get no advantage.
I did not make any such statement.

Then what is the hon. gentleman complaining about ? If he thinks that the whole advantage derived from the reduction of postage rates accrues to the inhabitants of large cities, he is mistaken. Only one-third of the postal revenue is derived from the cities. Two-thirds is derived outside the cities, so that two-thirds of the advantage accrues to the rural districts. Every one who senus a letter, be he a farmer or a millionaire, nas a corresponding advantage. If my hon. friend means to say that he represents a

constituency, the farmers in which never write letters, he would be correct in saying that they get no advantage from the reduction of postage. But if, like other farmers, they make a reasonable use of the mails, they get the same relative advantage as other Canadian citizens.

I think the county of Peel has been pretty well aired between the Postmaster General and its representative, and it is time that we should be allowed a few minutes for the other counties. The complaint is general that the amount received by the postmasters throughout the Dominion is very small, but there is no use to expect any increase while there is such a large deficit in the postal revenue.
1 look to the time when there will be a surplus, and then we will make a general raid on the Postmaster General for the increase of the salaries of the postmasters throughout the Dominion. In Nova Scotia, before confederation, when I represented my county for eight years, the direct salaries paid to postmasters were much better than they are now. Postmasters were paid salaries according to the services performed, but now they are paid a certain percentage.
I do not think any person wants to reduce the number of post offices in his own couuty, but the desire would be to increase them in several instances. So far, in all my appeals to the Postmaster General, I find that we cannot make any impression upon him. He is very pleasant when in the House, but when you want a particular favour from him for your own county, he is pretty rigid. In fact, there is no elasticity in him at all. I hope that after this he'will be a little more elastic and that we shall be able to get our daily mail betweeu Baddeck and Englishtown for which I have been ipleadidg all this time.

I hope the Postmaster General wall take the cue from the hon. members wTho nave spoken of reducing the post offices. You may do it in some of the counties where the people do not read and write, but I hope you will not attempt to reduce the number of post offices in my county. Most of the farmers in that county take a daily paper, and I am sure you will be doing them an injustice if you do not make it convenient for them to get that paper. As to the farmers contributing toward the expense of the post office, I think the farmers already contribute their share. They help to keep up the merchants, the bankers and others "who are benefited by cheap postage. Now as to the centralizing of post offices in large cities, I know that St. Martins le Grand in Old London is the head post office, and the only large post office in that city of over four millions of people, but I have never heard of any suggestion of a change because the city has
grown west. It seems to me it would be folly to tear down the post offices in Toronto and Montreal because they_ are not in the present centres of those cities. I do not think it would be1 wise for the government to spend more money building more post offices when those now in existence will do, even though they are not in the centre, of the city. I think that it would be much to the public advantage to have a system of free delivery in cities of from ten to twelve thousand inhabitants. Much time is wasted by people trudging to the post office, it may toe miles, two or three times a day to look into their boxes and see if there is anything for them. It js time that in these large towns postal matter should be delivered two or three times a day. I am pleased to see the reduction in postage. But there is one point worthy of consideration. I was in the little post office in my neighbourhood a few nights ago, and I saw the postmaster putting circulars into almost every box. He handed one to me. These were circulars from the United States that had come in a large bundle, each circular bearing a one cent stamp. Our government got no revenue from that. I asked the postmaster if he had sent the names of parties in that neighbourhood to the firm, and he said he thought they had secured a copy of the voters' list. We are carrying free a large amount of mail matter for the purpose of advertising quack medicines from otlier places, and I think it is time we had a change. The Postmaster General talks a great deal about plans that existed eighteen years ago. He talks back to hon. gentlemen on this side because he found such and such a system in existence when he took office. But you know we have had a growing time since then, and people have to pay a good deal more for everything they get. I do not know but that the Postmaster General should have a little of that growing time for the villages. The postmasters in towns and cities are well paid, and do little work. It would be a good thing if we could get some of this money from the cities and towns and give it to the rural districts.

As to the view taken by the Postmaster General of the statement made by the hon. member for Peel (Mr. Blain) I do not for one moment under-stand'the hon. member for Peel as agitating for a reduction in the number of post offices in that county. I understand the remark to have a more general application, perhaps to the whole province. There may be some counties which have too many post offices while some may have too few. For example, the county of North York, the constituency represented by the Postmaster General, has secured recently a number ot new post offices. But if the matter were equalized, probably Peel would have got one post office while North York might have got two. I take it that the remarks of the

lion, member for Peel were intended to have general application, and not by any means-
I suppose they were to apply to every place but Peel.

They were to have a general application. As to my own county, the Postmaster General since he came into office has been very generous. We have had only one post office closed. And I may tell the Postmaster General now, that I think it was a mistake to close that post office, for the simple reason that it was on a mail route, the carrier passed it every day in the year, and could just as well supply that office as not. The only difference, I suppose, would be that the postmaster would be paid at the rate of about $10 a year for keeping the post office open.
I am one who favours the extension of the postal system in the rural districts, and have advocated that time and again. I believe the reduction of postage from 3 cents to 2 cents is of far greater benefit to the large centres of population than it is to the rural districts, and that the rural districts, the farmers especially, have to make up the deficiency in the revenue of the postal system. For I do not expect ever to see the revenue of the Post Office Department meet the expenditure. I tell the Postmaster General plainly that 1 do not hope to see it. I think it would be a mistake to try to attain such an end. There is no more reason why the Postal Department should be made self-sustaining than there is why the Intercolonial Railway, which cost us $13,000,000 in five years more than the revenues accruing from it should be self-sustaining. There is no more reason why the post office should be self-sustaining than there is why the Department of Public Works should be self-sustaining. Who would think of making the St. Lawrence route pay ? We do not expect to get enough out of the canals to pay the interest on the expenditure we have made on that route. Why should we expect the Post Office Department, which interests every man, woman and child in the country, to be selfsustaining ?
